resource provider is deleted via host1 in this race window,
the association refresh in host2 fails because the provider
is gone. As a result, host2 has stale entries in the RT
compute_nodes dict and possible the ProviderTree cache.

This resolves the issue by simply handling the failure
to refresh assocations and remove the RT.compute_nodes entry,
like the fix for bug 1839674, so that on the next run of
update_available_resource on host2 it will re-create the
compute node (note this depends on the fix for bug 1839560 to
"re-create" the soft deleted compute node record) and the
resource provider.

Change-Id: Iffb802cf9c84550e919d5b2865d05fe172907190
Closes-Bug: #1841481
'}]
commit_message:
Clear RT.compute_nodes entry if re-balance update fails

During an ironic node rebalance from host1 to host2, there
can be a race where host2 detects the rebalance, adds the
ComputeNode object its ResourceTracker.compute_nodes dict
and then try to update/refresh associations for the resource
provider in placement. Between the time that host2 has
cached the ComputeNode object and refreshed associations in
placement, host1's update_available_resource periodic task
can run, detect it no longer manages the node, and consider
it orphaned and delete the compute node record from the nova
DB and the resource provider from placement. When the
resource provider is deleted via host1 in this race window,
the association refresh in host2 fails because the provider
is gone. As a result, host2 has stale entries in the RT
compute_nodes dict and possible the ProviderTree cache.

This resolves the issue by simply handling the failure
to refresh assocations and remove the RT.compute_nodes entry,
like the fix for bug 1839674, so that on the next run of
update_available_resource on host2 it will re-create the
compute node (note this depends on the fix for bug 1839560 to
"re-create" the soft deleted compute node record) and the
resource provider.

Change-Id: Iffb802cf9c84550e919d5b2865d05fe172907190
Closes-Bug: #1841481

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-23 15:43:14.000000000', 'message': "tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.
2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Change-Id: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

1. Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.

2. Remove the unnecessary blank line for tox.ini

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Change-Id: Ie837d376bb1a1d93367369d25140dd8a9d5ac14e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-25 20:31:39.000000000', 'message': "Add functional recreate test for bug 1841481

This is pretty hairy since it involves an ironic node
re-balance across two compute services and a race but
if you trust what is written in the test, which is
basically automating the log dive from the bug report,
this works and recreates the issue. The hairy bits are
in simulating the race because in the bug report things
are happening concurrently (obviously, it's a race across
two separate services on different compute hosts) but in
the test we're doing things in serial so we have to stub
out a few things to simulate what happens at each point
in time from the view of each service.

The main takeaways are that:

1. Once the node is re-balanced to host2, we cannot
   re-create the resource provider by simply running
   the update_available_resource periodic task, i.e.
   the issue is not self-healing.

2. The resource tracker on host2 has incorrectly cached
   in memory a ComputeNode and resource provider which are
   actually deleted so the cache is stale but we're not
   healing it automatically on failure.

Change-Id: I6d9e81bdea7e6080197d0840ebc75d2ebe7c8e96
Related-Bug: #1841481

commit_message:
Add functional recreate test for bug 1841481

This is pretty hairy since it involves an ironic node
re-balance across two compute services and a race but
if you trust what is written in the test, which is
basically automating the log dive from the bug report,
this works and recreates the issue. The hairy bits are
in simulating the race because in the bug report things
are happening concurrently (obviously, it's a race across
two separate services on different compute hosts) but in
the test we're doing things in serial so we have to stub
out a few things to simulate what happens at each point
in time from the view of each service.

The main takeaways are that:

1. Once the node is re-balanced to host2, we cannot
   re-create the resource provider by simply running
   the update_available_resource periodic task, i.e.
   the issue is not self-healing.

2. The resource tracker on host2 has incorrectly cached
   in memory a ComputeNode and resource provider which are
   actually deleted so the cache is stale but we're not
   healing it automatically on failure.

Change-Id: I6d9e81bdea7e6080197d0840ebc75d2ebe7c8e96
Related-Bug: #1841481

commit_message:
Update process for R+1 week

Move R+1 week process items to the top of the document, remove obsolete
steps and merge the remaning ones with pre-PTG steps. Include weekly
email content. Move the step about proposing a schedule for the next
release to "between m-2 and m-3", as this is when we actually do that.

Change-Id: I5a4a7e5e059156139944a09e4d7813bd11ec1c5a

commit_message:
Migrate grenade jobs to py3

As part of community goal of dropping py27 support[1], we are
moving the devstack to py3 by default[2]. That will make grenade job
to perform upgrade from py2 to py3 which will not work (we have seen
the failure in neutron-grenade job).

To avoid existing grenade py2 job break, this commit moves grenade
jobs to py3 which is what we planned as part dropping the py2 support.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649097/12
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010938.html

Change-Id: I6216868fc5405cc3f3a14cd5f32a38d778e64c2d

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

sahara-dashboard is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/
Change-Id: I9bbca7e2d317090dc2d05d08ccf8c45206cd160c

commit_message:
Bring py27 tests back

Since defaulting to py3 our 2.7 jobs have actually ran against python 3
due to basepython not declared on our 27 evironments. This patch will
change that.

Change-Id: I4d97c0577460949e8636e9f26b1d4b60b109f5d1
(cherry picked from commit 3c57b78653bc0fdc91ab29e42e72aeffda07c4da)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-15 14:48:24.000000000', 'message': "Switch to use cast method in dhcp_ready_on_ports method

When DHCP agent reports to the neutron-server which ports are
ready, it was using call() method from rpc client.
That caused blocking dhcp agent's dhcp_ready_ports_loop thread which
blocks to send info about other ready ports if there are any.

Method call() should be used when RPC caller returns a value to the
caller but that's not the case here. On neutron server side this
RPC method is only calling provisioning_complete() method to
finish provisioning of ports. And is not returning anything.

So to make sending dhcp ready ports to neutron-server much faster
this patch switch to use cast() method from rpc client.
This method don't block to wait for return value from RPC caller.

Change-Id: Ie119693854aa283b863a1eac2bdae3330c2b6a9d
Closes-Bug: #1850864
(cherry picked from commit 1a686fb401eca1843b81292fc88c13a2e6fd274d)
"}]
commit_message:
Switch to use cast method in dhcp_ready_on_ports method

When DHCP agent reports to the neutron-server which ports are
ready, it was using call() method from rpc client.
That caused blocking dhcp agent's dhcp_ready_ports_loop thread which
blocks to send info about other ready ports if there are any.

Method call() should be used when RPC caller returns a value to the
caller but that's not the case here. On neutron server side this
RPC method is only calling provisioning_complete() method to
finish provisioning of ports. And is not returning anything.

So to make sending dhcp ready ports to neutron-server much faster
this patch switch to use cast() method from rpc client.
This method don't block to wait for return value from RPC caller.

Change-Id: Ie119693854aa283b863a1eac2bdae3330c2b6a9d
Closes-Bug: #1850864
(cherry picked from commit 1a686fb401eca1843b81292fc88c13a2e6fd274d)

SO IT IS. I can't read."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-11 07:18:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I don't think we want to highlight the fact that some projects are still testing with other interfaces and will support all the panels of python possible. This is up to the project's governance, not a TC resolution.

When people check this page, I sure hope there is only a single message out there: Go for python3.

I can be convinced otherwise though, because clarity doesn't hurt.
(If we make it look like it's a very exceptional case, I might be willing to move to a positive vote)."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-09-11 14:06:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

(1 comment)

> I don't think we want to highlight the fact that some projects are
 > still testing with other interfaces and will support all the panels
 > of python possible. This is up to the project's governance, not a
 > TC resolution.
 > 
 > When people check this page, I sure hope there is only a single
 > message out there: Go for python3.
 > 
 > I can be convinced otherwise though, because clarity doesn't hurt.
 > (If we make it look like it's a very exceptional case, I might be
 > willing to move to a positive vote).

That is not that Tempest and its plugins want to test extra python version as a choice, it is mandatory for them because of testing nature.

same comment why I think this is needed- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/679798/2/reference/runtimes/ussuri.rst@23"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-09-17 02:27:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Devil's advocate: there's nothing stopping you from running a Python3 Tempest against a Python2 cloud, so why do we need to make an exception?"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-09-17 14:40:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Devil's advocate: there's nothing stopping you from running a
 > Python3 Tempest against a Python2 cloud, so why do we need to make
 > an exception?

Whether OpenStack services (ussuri version) can run or officially support the python 2 (or what all 3.x version) cloud is the main motive of testing runtime right?

So Tempest has to support the few extra older python version as per its design and explicitly mention that in this doc will help Temepst users to understand that ussuri version of Tempest can be run against python2.7 cloud."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-09-18 02:29:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1

> Whether OpenStack services (ussuri version) can run or officially support the python 2 (or what all 3.x version) cloud is the main motive of testing runtime right?

Yes.

> So Tempest has to support the few extra older python version as per its design

But Tempest is not an OpenStack service.

> and explicitly mention that in this doc will help Temepst users to understand that ussuri version of Tempest can be run against python2.7 cloud.

But that has nothing to do with what version of Python Tempest runs under. It could be written in Golang for all we care and it would still run fine against a cloud running on either 2.7 or 3.6 because it interacts with the cloud only using the ReST APIs.

In fact to the extent that Tempest depends on libraries like oslo.config that are free to drop 2.7 support, it may well be forced to run under Python 3.x. But that's fine, because it wouldn't preclude it running against older clouds.

It's up to Tempest to document which versions of OpenStack it runs against, and up to the runtime pages for past releases to document which versions of Python those releases were tested against. IMHO we don't want the Ussuri page to contain information about past releases."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-20 14:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1 -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-09-24 16:15:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2019-09-24 23:02:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I agree with the concerns raised by Zane. I help maintain a tempest plugin, and want to drop support to python2 and <python3.6 in Ussuri if possible - Tempest and its plugins can be installed anywhere, and that has nothing to do with the python version supported by the cloud that they are testing.. 

I know we don't provide any recommendations from where tempest can be invoked... but I doubt anyone expects tempest+plugins to continue to support deprecated python versions just so they can co-install them alongside the cloud they intend to test (which is the theoretical scenario I'm reading here)..."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-09-26 19:08:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-10-08 22:07:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I agree with the concerns raised by Zane. I help maintain a tempest
 > plugin, and want to drop support to python2 and <python3.6 in
 > Ussuri if possible - Tempest and its plugins can be installed
 > anywhere, and that has nothing to do with the python version
 > supported by the cloud that they are testing..
 > 
 > I know we don't provide any recommendations from where tempest can
 > be invoked... but I doubt anyone expects tempest+plugins to
 > continue to support deprecated python versions just so they can
 > co-install them alongside the cloud they intend to test (which is
 > the theoretical scenario I'm reading here)...

 > I agree with the concerns raised by Zane. I help maintain a tempest
 > plugin, and want to drop support to python2 and <python3.6 in
 > Ussuri if possible - Tempest and its plugins can be installed
 > anywhere, and that has nothing to do with the python version
 > supported by the cloud that they are testing..
 > 
 > I know we don't provide any recommendations from where tempest can
 > be invoked... but I doubt anyone expects tempest+plugins to
 > continue to support deprecated python versions just so they can
 > co-install them alongside the cloud they intend to test (which is
 > the theoretical scenario I'm reading here)...

This is the main reason I want to have Tempest and its Plugin supported version to be mentioned explicitly.

If your Tempest plugin is branchless and supports the stable branches also where py2.7 is official supported version then, plugin has to support the py2.7 until all supported stable branches are without py2.7 support.

Regarding testing new or old cloud, until you do not keep testing the Tempest and plugin with py2.7 you cannot guarantee that it can run on py2.7 or not. For example, if I use Tempest 2x.0.0 to test Stein cloud and do not keep Tempest 2x.0.0 compatible with py2.7 then it can be broken at any time."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-10-08 22:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> (1 comment)

Yeah, this is a good point. If we go with using a specific tag then yes. But the overall goal of branchless model was Tempest master can be used to test the newer or older cloud.'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2019-10-08 23:45:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> This is the main reason I want to have Tempest and its Plugin supported version to be mentioned explicitly.
> If your Tempest plugin is branchless and supports the stable branches also where py2.7 is official supported version then, plugin has to support the py2.7 until all supported stable branches are without py2.7 support.
> Regarding testing new or old cloud, until you do not keep testing the Tempest and plugin with py2.7 you cannot guarantee that it can run on py2.7 or not. For example, if I use Tempest 2x.0.0 to test Stein cloud and do not keep Tempest 2x.0.0 compatible with py2.7 then it can be broken at any time.

Hi Ghanshyam, 

Yes, I think plugins can still be branchless - and used to test older OpenStack clouds even while dropping support for python2.7. Since tempest tests communicate with the cloud via REST API calls, the version of python shouldn't matter... I was suggesting that we do not take the burden of maintaining python2.7 support for tempest and the plugins... As suggested inline, users have a choice of installing an older version of tempest that supports python2.7 and python3.x if they want it... From Ussuri, if we dropped the python2.7 jobs and support, users will install tempest only in python3 environments and run their tests - nothing else should change... Am I missing something? :)"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-10-09 02:05:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> > This is the main reason I want to have Tempest and its Plugin
 > supported version to be mentioned explicitly.
 > > If your Tempest plugin is branchless and supports the stable
 > branches also where py2.7 is official supported version then,
 > plugin has to support the py2.7 until all supported stable branches
 > are without py2.7 support.
 > > Regarding testing new or old cloud, until you do not keep testing
 > the Tempest and plugin with py2.7 you cannot guarantee that it can
 > run on py2.7 or not. For example, if I use Tempest 2x.0.0 to test
 > Stein cloud and do not keep Tempest 2x.0.0 compatible with py2.7
 > then it can be broken at any time.
 > 
 > Hi Ghanshyam,
 > 
 > Yes, I think plugins can still be branchless - and used to test
 > older OpenStack clouds even while dropping support for python2.7.
 > Since tempest tests communicate with the cloud via REST API calls,
 > the version of python shouldn't matter... I was suggesting that we
 > do not take the burden of maintaining python2.7 support for tempest
 > and the plugins... As suggested inline, users have a choice of
 > installing an older version of tempest that supports python2.7 and
 > python3.x if they want it... From Ussuri, if we dropped the
 > python2.7 jobs and support, users will install tempest only in
 > python3 environments and run their tests - nothing else should
 > change... Am I missing something? :)

There are two things actually,
1. Tempest or plugin do interact with services via API call but whether Tempest source code can run on py2.7 or not. I should be able to run Tempest on py2.7 env.

2. Tempest and plugin master branch need to officially support all the supported stable branch in upstream (not Extended Maintenance) so if I tell to use Tempest tag on supported stable branch testing then the whole point of branchless is gone. branchless goal is to test all stable + master branches with the same version/set of tests tools.

From Tempest and tempest plugins, we cannot remove the support until stable/train is Extended Maintenance. If we do then we might break the compatibility of tests tooling."}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-10-15 13:51:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1

100% agree with what Zane said. We can require python 3 going forward for Tempest, and it can still test clouds that run on python 2 just fine.

The only question is if newer tempest can be co-installed with an older OpenStack environment running on Python 2. I don't believe we've ever guaranteed that anyway (devstack installs tempest in a virtualenv), and I don't recall anyone asking for it. I would be fine with dropping co-installability."}, {'account_id': 9542, 'date': '2019-10-15 15:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-10-18 14:27:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1

I am RC ing my own patch, as this was added as a follow on for feedback on the orignal patch.

I think we don't need to highlight the requirements here, as the tempest team will be doing that already"}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-10-18 17:05:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I think this proposal is incomplete without a discussion of the support burden this imposes on oslo... or doesn't, depending on what road we go down.  I thinkw e should discuss it in the TC office hours on the 24th where the general topic of python 2 discontinuation will be discussed."}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-10-18 21:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1 -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-10-23 18:44:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

ML thread to get user feedback if they need py2.7 support otherwise I am ok now after considering all points and opinions here. thanks for that. - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010317.html'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-28 10:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-15 18:04:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

commit_message:
Explictly highlight Tempest python versions

Tempest is branchless and as a result has a different set of python
testing requirements. We should not stop testing older python versions
until the Tempest and its plugins no longer test OpenStack versions
that test on them.

Change-Id: I0c0072550f59d533b79952b32dd0b16a253ad2fc
Signed-off-by: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

mistral-dashboard is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/
Change-Id: Ib39cbe4f526d5ace03f959e21eb4907c97ac7b65

commit_message:
FEMDC is now a part of the Edge Computing Group

The FEMDC SIG has suspended its activities over the past year to
get more directly involved in the OSF Edge Computing Group. It will
continue its activities within that group.

In order to make the Edge Computing Group easier to find when you
look for OpenStack special interest groups, it should be mentioned in
the OpenStack SIG list.

Change-Id: I62bc8f70278f505f315c8bee0935c841c5b88360

commit_message:
Pin ceph dashboard containers on a specific tag

Since in OSP context we want to rely on more stable ceph dashboard
content, in this review we pin the grafana/prometheus/alertmanager
and node-exporter containers to a specific tag suggested by ceph
team.

Change-Id: I2b308dea3c9e2380185fd3cce68a3aad5842a730
(cherry picked from commit f4d4a229ad74cba30c2d9dfcd057cdace0f553f4)

commit_message:
Fix multinode gate after switch to Python 3

The compute1 node of multinode gate was not explicitly set to use Python
3 and failed after Nova dropped support for it. This commit fixes that.

Change-Id: I2f0376091af67bb79dcef51974d11e7a40bb0e4c

commit_message:
Add option to redefine locale

Since CentOS do not support C.UTF-8 locale[1] we're placing system
default inside openrc file. If locale can't be found from gathered facts
it's defaulted to C.UTF-8.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1361965

Change-Id: I304bacf0e586b119ac41757b96fa237d2839aaf5
(cherry picked from commit b79fade9098af471744c1842951b2e34235b62b0)

commit_message:
Add option to redefine locale

Since CentOS do not support C.UTF-8 locale[1] we're placing system
default inside openrc file. If locale can't be found from gathered facts
it's defaulted to C.UTF-8.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1361965

Change-Id: I304bacf0e586b119ac41757b96fa237d2839aaf5
(cherry picked from commit b79fade9098af471744c1842951b2e34235b62b0)

Qinling could not be deployed due to use of an undefined variable

commit_message:
WIP: Convert nova-live-migration job to zuulv3

This changes the nova-live-migration job from using legacy
devstack-gate setup to running with zuulv3 configuration.

Some of the setup is similar to how the nova-next zuulv3
job is done with a post-run role to execute the live migration
hook script and evacuate test script.

Since the nova-grenade-multinode and nova-live-migration jobs
both use the same live migration hooks script and the former
job is still using legacy devstack-gate setup some changes need
to be made to the script to account for the changes in how the
jobs run the script.

Change-Id: If553c589952b6bfa05cb13cf05d183c6e5bb7182

commit_message:
Revert the Xenial-tagged images to Xenial

This change builds Xenial images for the Xenial-tagged Ceph
containers to overwrite the Bionic images that incorrectly
overwrote the Xenial images two days ago when
https://review.opendev.org/693577 was merged.

A separate patch set will be created to generate Bionic images
with the correct tags.

Change-Id: I06568e2a6d86e8af5af8ca1b836267eb8f1ede7e

commit_message:
Restart mysql when package is installed

When running galera_server role with galera_upgrade=true
it uninstalls mariadb and installs again. In some distros, like CentOS,
mariadb don't start automatically after installation, so upgrade fails.

This patch adds handler on package installation, which will be
triggered when package state is changed.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/694759/
Change-Id: I23811cfaf23007c5da1860e78397be380d67403b
Related-bug: 1628720
(cherry picked from commit efc965f00fc515a46d03fcf22270ebc7bb8e4791)

[{'created': '2019-11-05 08:00:04.000000000', 'message': 'Only delete pod from CNI registry after unplugging the vif

We can get the DELETED event before kubelet calls CNI DEL on the same
pod. This will lead to a case where we remove the pod from the CNI
registry before unplugging the vif. In this case the CNI DEL request will
fail due absence of info of the tap interfaces. This effects OVS as we

commit_message:
Only delete pod from CNI registry after unplugging the vif

We can get the DELETED event before kubelet calls CNI DEL on the same
pod. This will lead to a case where we remove the pod from the CNI
registry before unplugging the vif. In this case the CNI DEL request will
fail due absence of info of the tap interfaces. This effects OVS as we
are left with tap interfaces whose one end is still attached to br-int.

Change-Id: I5fda411e938319a00590f7dcfd2e6f37b7e2194c
Signed-off-by: Nayan Deshmukh <n.deshmukh@samsung.com>
Signed-off-by: Paweł Suder <p.suder@samsung.com>
Closes-Bug: 1849626

commit_message:
Add tempest bionic image

This patch set adds an ubuntu bionic-based image for OpenStack tempest.

Also: place in a fix to the SUSE image so the build can succeed.

Change-Id: Id6d615e81b5c82043aec08755cf442eed32bf236
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tlam@omegaprime.dev>

commit_message:
Update to use relative imports

This patch updates the prometheus-openstack-exporter to use the relative
module imports instead.

Change-Id: I4ef6f212bebb48422ff27d58e117a713f6392aca
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tlam@omegaprime.dev>

commit_message:
Drop common-db tag from db_sync task

galnce_db_sync has no relation to common-db, and independent step
during glance configuration. common-db tag should be applied only
to the common tasks

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/694759
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/694759

commit_message:
Clean up stale values overrides

As all feature specific value overrides are moved into the component's
values_overrides folder to be used by zuul's feature gate, the old
overrides should be removed to reduce confusion as they are unused.

Change-Id: Ieaf35a8147061da356fdfa46c73673457af1f3d1
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

commit_message:
Remove netpol from default scripts

As network policy jobs in zuul are moved to be run by the feature gate,
usage of them in old scripts should be taken out to avoid confusion and
potential problem where netpol cause unexpected connection failure. This
patch set removes the remanant of these netpol's.

Change-Id: I1ce86d27ca4f708b17d848d742ba840156d4ef6c
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

commit_message:
Adding missing tag for dynamic-address-fact task

Certain playbooks require dynamic facts at runtime and when
using tags like project-config, these tasks need to be called,
otherwise the template evaluation stops trying to resolve the facts.

Change-Id: I40e55671aed8df741e27ce8b2581b293a344afc0
(cherry picked from commit 096691d2ebfedfe5d66fd60f6a674bb69ae5e533)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-13 16:47:21.000000000', 'message': "Add option to redefine locale

Since CentOS do not support C.UTF-8 locale[1] we're placing system
default inside openrc file. If locale can't be found from gathered facts
it's defaulted to C.UTF-8.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1361965

Change-Id: I304bacf0e586b119ac41757b96fa237d2839aaf5
"}]
commit_message:
Add option to redefine locale

Since CentOS do not support C.UTF-8 locale[1] we're placing system
default inside openrc file. If locale can't be found from gathered facts
it's defaulted to C.UTF-8.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1361965

Change-Id: I304bacf0e586b119ac41757b96fa237d2839aaf5

commit_message:
New charms & interfaces for MySQL8

Add mysql-router and mysql-innodb-cluster charms for clustering with
MySQL 8. Also add interfaces for both charms.

Depends-On: Icb9e9c6f9c61de406b9e010d66160a5c1d75b61b
Change-Id: Id3e0516c838efd653834aeeed8fbe3a40dcaabc4

The complexity involved in the allocate_for_instance implementation
for Neutron means that anytime one needs to debug this code, they
basically have to re-learn what everything is and is doing, because
the variable names are either inadequate, or the methods are doing
more than their name implies, like validation methods also changing
parameters by reference. And the docstrings on several methods are
just plain wrong or missing information.

This patch attempts to clean up some of that confusion by renaming
some variables for clarity of type and purpose, adds comments and
cleans up docstrings.

Change-Id: I4440a19370da9807cc8c32b681542c7048c9977e

Change-Id: I4440a19370da9807cc8c32b681542c7048c9977e

commit_message:
Clean variable names and docs around neutron allocate_for_instance

The complexity involved in the allocate_for_instance implementation
for Neutron means that anytime one needs to debug this code, they
basically have to re-learn what everything is and is doing, because
the variable names are either inadequate, or the methods are doing
more than their name implies, like validation methods also changing
parameters by reference. And the docstrings on several methods are
just plain wrong or missing information.

This patch attempts to clean up some of that confusion by renaming
some variables for clarity of type and purpose, adds comments and
cleans up docstrings.

Change-Id: I4440a19370da9807cc8c32b681542c7048c9977e

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-10-17 12:33:26.000000000', 'message': 'Delete obsolete grub-legacy code

GRUB legacy does not support GPT disks, it can not work on
disks which are > 4T. Since centos 7 and ubuntu after 9.09 have
switched to grub2 which supports GPT partition disk, and anaconda
installs grub2 automatically. So those code became obsolete and
can be delete safely.

Change-Id: Ic1d5a45aecea1ac1f794ee474c39b46a204fb2b9
Closes-bug: #1634073
'}]
commit_message:
Delete obsolete grub-legacy code

GRUB legacy does not support GPT disks, it can not work on
disks which are > 4T. Since centos 7 and ubuntu after 9.09 have
switched to grub2 which supports GPT partition disk, and anaconda
installs grub2 automatically. So those code became obsolete and
can be delete safely.

Change-Id: Ic1d5a45aecea1ac1f794ee474c39b46a204fb2b9
Closes-bug: #1634073

commit_message:
Add extra unit test for get_cmdline_from_pid function

In patch [1] get_cmdline_from_pid function was modified to be able
to parse process' cmdline files with arguments separated by space
instead of '\0' char.
This patch adds one extra UT and small refactor which was pointed
in comments to [1] but which I was not able to change there.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/647605/

Change-Id: Ibd91d0472a686eca79a1126154d9cdf4587c1a19
Related-Bug: #1820870
(cherry picked from commit dcc3d3c7548eb92634b84d5376a73f78421ba23f)

[{'account_id': 31314, 'date': '2019-11-20 18:58:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-11-20 18:59:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

it's no longer supported in Ansible 2.9

Signed-off-by: Khaled Elkhawaga <k.elkhawaga@gmail.com>

commit_message:
doc: add known limitation about attaching SR-IOV ports

Nova does not currently support attaching SR-IOV ports to
existing instances, you can only create a server with an
SR-IOV port at this time. This adds an item about that
limitation to the SR-IOV admin docs.

Change-Id: I0a954de724384a81cb45446da20fa6b17d4bd63a
Related-Bug: #1708433
(cherry picked from commit 60a9248b17cad8d2e7dd49cea120348dda99dc2b)
(cherry picked from commit 7859941647077a567fc1d546652dc738273328f0)

commit_message:
Splits STIG yum add/removes

In order to prevent RPM database corruption on the target hosts, this
change splits the STIG yum add/remove tasks into two separate plays.

Change-Id: I68751339d5b4cbfb61b8e3cf4ffbfeb47ea5fd76
Closes-Bug: #1851954

[{'created': '2019-11-19 20:54:29.000000000', 'message': "Remove references to writable LDAP from documentation

Keystone removed support for writable LDAP backends in Ocata. Prior to
that it was deprecated for several releases. This commit removes
references to those configuration options since they are silently
ignored. This cleans up the configuration files and doesn't give the
impression that functionality is still supported.

Relevant release notes that advertize the removal:

  https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/keystone/ocata.html#relnotes-11-0-0-origin-stable-ocata-other-notes

Change-Id: Id05247d004ee7d189dff3ec867a6ec11dfc40e9b
"}]
commit_message:
Remove references to writable LDAP from documentation

Keystone removed support for writable LDAP backends in Ocata. Prior to
that it was deprecated for several releases. This commit removes
references to those configuration options since they are silently
ignored. This cleans up the configuration files and doesn't give the
impression that functionality is still supported.

Relevant release notes that advertize the removal:

  https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/keystone/ocata.html#relnotes-11-0-0-origin-stable-ocata-other-notes

Change-Id: Id05247d004ee7d189dff3ec867a6ec11dfc40e9b

subject: WIP: Support shared nova cell controllers
messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-09-25 17:02:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-11-21 11:20:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-25 17:02:14.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Support shared nova cell controllers

Extracted some parts of the original patch into this one to make it
simpler, since we won't be supporting shared cell controllers in the
first pass and the namespacing complicates the upgrade process.

Partially Implements: blueprint support-nova-cells
Co-Authored-By: Doug Szumski <doug@stackhpc.com>

commit_message:
WIP: Support shared nova cell controllers

Extracted some parts of the original patch into this one to make it
simpler, since we won't be supporting shared cell controllers in the
first pass and the namespacing complicates the upgrade process.

Implements: blueprint nova-cells-shared-controllers
Co-Authored-By: Doug Szumski <doug@stackhpc.com>

Change-Id: I965ac8d5d8caee589adddaae2456642623dabd40

[{'created': '2019-11-20 14:02:55.000000000', 'message': 'Get rid of docker removing in post_upgrade tasks.

When upgrading from Rocky to Stein we moved also from using the docker
container engine into Podman. To ensure that every single docker container
was removed after the upgrade a post_upgrade task was added which made
use of the tripleo-docker-rm role that removed the container. In this cycle,
from Stein to Train both the Undercloud and Overcloud work with Podman, so

Change-Id: I5c9ab55ec6ff332056a426a76e150ea3c9063c6e
(cherry picked from commit 4cbae84c75e713f0bc3d09c5843267dbae12c7ca)

commit_message:
Get rid of docker removing in post_upgrade tasks.

When upgrading from Rocky to Stein we moved also from using the docker
container engine into Podman. To ensure that every single docker container
was removed after the upgrade a post_upgrade task was added which made
use of the tripleo-docker-rm role that removed the container. In this cycle,
from Stein to Train both the Undercloud and Overcloud work with Podman, so
there is no need to remove any docker container anymore.

This patch removes all the tripleo-docker-rm post-upgrade task and in those
services which only included a single task, the post-upgrade-tasks section
is also erased.

Change-Id: I5c9ab55ec6ff332056a426a76e150ea3c9063c6e
(cherry picked from commit 4cbae84c75e713f0bc3d09c5843267dbae12c7ca)

commit_message:
Disable overcloud image validation

To speed up CI and development process it would be better to disable
this script. CI will fail anyway even without this validation. Users
will be able to enable it if/when they decides to use tripleo-upgrade
for production upgrade.

Closes-bug: #1844567
Change-Id: Ia5a767491c2f297b396c5cc937c1495e4267a4e3
(cherry picked from commit 72dd2c49e37db7ed014f297e3b7aad8dc22f60fe)

commit_message:
[Configuration] Remove the build documentation.

Remove the build of the documentation from tox, the project doesn't use
sphinx. That fix an error during the build of the documentation, because
the configuration file for sphinx is not found.

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Patch to fix RPC selection problem after upgrade

Stable (Stein & earlier) only - nova cells change fixed this in Train.

Nova services communicate via RPC. RPC  version selection is done after
service start. Restart of all nova services present in list
 “nova_services_require_nova_conf”
 is needed for correct RPC version selection.

Only nova services located on the same node as “nova-compute”
were restarted till now. This fix restarts nova services on all nodes.

Change-Id: Idaf857b4894deb024f839263503a97332e3dc9af
Closes-Bug: #1847990

subject: Fix restart policy after MariaDB recovery
messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-11-20 19:11:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-11-20 19:52:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2019-11-21 08:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-20 19:11:33.000000000', 'message': "Fix restart policy after MariaDB recovery

After performing a recovery of MariaDB, the mariadb containers are left
without a restart policy. This leaves them unable to recover from the
crash of a single galera node. There is another issue, in that the
'master' node is left in a bootstrap configuration, with the
--wsrep-new-cluster argument configured as BOOTSTRAP_ARGS.

This change fixes these issues by removing the restart policy of 'no'
from the 'slave' containers, and recreating the master container without
the restart policy or bootstrap arguments.

Change-Id: I36c875611931163ca2c29ae93b71d3af64cb197c
Closes-Bug: #1851594
(cherry picked from commit f979ae1f8ee182a8bc6fde4b23b95a460cb81488)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix restart policy after MariaDB recovery

After performing a recovery of MariaDB, the mariadb containers are left
without a restart policy. This leaves them unable to recover from the
crash of a single galera node. There is another issue, in that the
'master' node is left in a bootstrap configuration, with the
--wsrep-new-cluster argument configured as BOOTSTRAP_ARGS.

This change fixes these issues by removing the restart policy of 'no'
from the 'slave' containers, and recreating the master container without
the restart policy or bootstrap arguments.

Change-Id: I36c875611931163ca2c29ae93b71d3af64cb197c
Closes-Bug: #1851594
(cherry picked from commit f979ae1f8ee182a8bc6fde4b23b95a460cb81488)

commit_message:
Fix restart policy after MariaDB recovery

After performing a recovery of MariaDB, the mariadb containers are left
without a restart policy. This leaves them unable to recover from the
crash of a single galera node. There is another issue, in that the
'master' node is left in a bootstrap configuration, with the
--wsrep-new-cluster argument configured as BOOTSTRAP_ARGS.

This change fixes these issues by removing the restart policy of 'no'
from the 'slave' containers, and recreating the master container without
the restart policy or bootstrap arguments.

Change-Id: I36c875611931163ca2c29ae93b71d3af64cb197c
Closes-Bug: #1851594

commit_message:
Parse MariaDB log messages in different formats into Fluentd

MariaDB logs contain two different log message formats, one output
from mysqld and one from mysqld_safe. This patch splits the message
formats by tag and parses them separately.

Change-Id: I58857be67ae387eeda7487811a6af85b0f95970c
Closes-Bug: #1845629

commit_message:
Fix lower-constraints gate after switch to py36

To make lower-constraints gate work with Python 3 we need to upgrade
eventlet to 0.22.0. Also it's now safe to drop Python 2 entry for
Sphinx.

Change-Id: I50663c428cf5524526055374e53964b86609f653
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/

[{'created': '2019-09-19 21:54:59.000000000', 'message': "Use the IPv6 documentation prefix as the default cidr

Don't use a cidr which might be routable, instead use the
IPv6 documentation prefix which should be dropped and
filtered by routers according to RFC 3849.

Change-Id: I5efc30ca633118a5fb517dace77aaffb49fd2013
"}]
commit_message:
Use the IPv6 documentation prefix as the default cidr

Don't use a cidr which might be routable, instead use the
IPv6 documentation prefix which should be dropped and
filtered by routers according to RFC 3849.

Change-Id: I5efc30ca633118a5fb517dace77aaffb49fd2013

I am actually not clear why the refactors were backported and they are unrelated to the bug I backported. Renat can maybe speak to that work.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2019-11-21 09:00:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Well, yes, your assumption is right. That refactoring patch is needed for another one that closes a particular bug. It's my regular style to split the big work into certain clear steps: first improve the existing code, then fix the problem. For backportable things I usually try to avoid that though and include everything into a single patch. So excuse me. I simply didn't pay attention to this aspect this time."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-21 10:06:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

The parent patch proposes the release model change and
This is the first release for Ussuri.

Glance v1 support was dropped since the previous release
(i.e. Train release 16.0.0), so the major version is bumped.

This release would fix failures of the docs job in several horizon
plugins which is caused by the inconsistency between horizon 16.0.0

commit_message:
Release horizon 17.0.0 (ussuri)

The parent patch proposes the release model change and
This is the first release for Ussuri.

Glance v1 support was dropped since the previous release
(i.e. Train release 16.0.0), so the major version is bumped.

This release would fix failures of the docs job in several horizon
plugins which is caused by the inconsistency between horizon 16.0.0
(train) and python-novaclient 16.0.0 (ussuri).

Drop the "estimated" if date is "TBD"

"TBD" if we don't have a date set yet.

commit_message:
Introduce molecule tests in the tripleo-upgrade role

This patch adds the first structure to
run molecule and test this role

It includes a basic escenario to run the tripleo-upgrade
role without parameters.

Change-Id: I5b569ef8dca549581c918ee6bbde1234c68aa5a6

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

kuryr-libnetwork is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/
Change-Id: I3776d17e05b565e05f84266eef0df15374a43a89

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-24 07:18:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix controller worker graceful shutdown

Fix an issue that prevents graceful shutdown of controller workers.

cotyledon.Service.terminate function is by definition the graceful
termination function and doesn't have any 'graceful' optional boolean
argument (https://cotyledon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html).

Because of this error, message_listener.wait() was never called in the
consumers' termination functions, so flows could be interrupted before
completion and could leave resources such as load balancer in a
PENDING_* provisioning state.

By default cotyledon.Service terminates the server after a timeout if
the worker could not shutdown itself gracefully. The default value
for the timeout is 60 seconds and can be overriden using the
graceful_shutdown_timeout setting in octavia.conf

Story: 2006603
Task: 36770

Change-Id: I3f776bd018246897c9a889699a2d0ecbbfbb7098
"}, {'created': '2019-09-30 07:05:21.000000000', 'message': "Fix controller worker graceful shutdown

Fix an issue that prevents graceful shutdown of controller workers.

cotyledon.Service.terminate function is by definition the graceful
termination function and doesn't have any 'graceful' optional boolean
argument (https://cotyledon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html).

Because of this error, message_listener.wait() was never called in the
consumers' termination functions, so flows could be interrupted before
completion and could leave resources such as load balancer in a
PENDING_* provisioning state.

By default cotyledon.Service terminates the server after a timeout if
the worker could not shutdown itself gracefully. The default value
for the timeout is 60 seconds and can be overriden using the
graceful_shutdown_timeout setting in octavia.conf

Story: 2006603
Task: 36770

Change-Id: I3f776bd018246897c9a889699a2d0ecbbfbb7098
"}, {'created': '2019-10-11 09:45:44.000000000', 'message': "Fix controller worker graceful shutdown

Fix an issue that prevents graceful shutdown of controller workers.

cotyledon.Service.terminate function is by definition the graceful
termination function and doesn't have any 'graceful' optional boolean
argument (https://cotyledon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html).

Because of this error, message_listener.wait() was never called in the
consumers' termination functions, so flows could be interrupted before
completion and could leave resources such as load balancer in a
PENDING_* provisioning state.

By default cotyledon.Service terminates the server after a timeout if
the worker could not shutdown itself gracefully. The default value
for the timeout is 300 seconds (set in devstack plugin) and can be
overriden using the graceful_shutdown_timeout setting in octavia.conf
The default value will be updated to a lower value when work on
persistant taskflow will be merged.

Story: 2006603
Task: 36770

cotyledon.Service.terminate function is by definition the graceful
termination function and doesn't have any 'graceful' optional boolean
argument (https://cotyledon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html).

Because of this error, message_listener.wait() was never called in the
consumers' termination functions, so flows could be interrupted before
completion and could leave resources such as load balancer in a
PENDING_* provisioning state.

By default cotyledon.Service terminates the server after a timeout if
the worker could not shutdown itself gracefully. The default value
for the timeout is 300 seconds (set in devstack plugin) and can be
overriden using the graceful_shutdown_timeout setting in octavia.conf
The default value will be updated to a lower value when work on
persistant taskflow will be merged.

commit_message:
Fix controller worker graceful shutdown

Fix an issue that prevents graceful shutdown of controller workers.

cotyledon.Service.terminate function is by definition the graceful
termination function and doesn't have any 'graceful' optional boolean
argument (https://cotyledon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api.html).

Because of this error, message_listener.wait() was never called in the
consumers' termination functions, so flows could be interrupted before
completion and could leave resources such as load balancer in a
PENDING_* provisioning state.

By default cotyledon.Service terminates the server after a timeout if
the worker could not shutdown itself gracefully. The default value
for the timeout is 300 seconds (set in devstack plugin) and can be
overriden using the graceful_shutdown_timeout setting in octavia.conf
The default value will be updated to a lower value when work on
persistant taskflow will be merged.

Story: 2006603
Task: 36770

Change-Id: I3f776bd018246897c9a889699a2d0ecbbfbb7098

commit_message:
Disable journald-remote playbook

The journald-remote playbook is disabled by default until
https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/2376 has been
incorporated in current systemd packages.

Change-Id: Ie70729eaad095b52813610b94c6618c84b05c148
Closes-Bug: #1853198

[{'created': '2019-11-20 16:36:13.000000000', 'message': 'Make the mistral devstack jobs non-voting in Rocky

These jobs are problematic when trying to merge a security fix into
Rocky[1]. This change has passed and merged intro master, Train and
Stein. It even passed CI once in Rocky (on Nov 19th) but then failed
in the gate.

This change disables CI to allow this security fix to land and will
be reverted afterwards where we can investigate the unstable CI.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694733/

Change-Id: I26d587241f765b13e135be5c4cf90976903af9ea
'}]
commit_message:
Make the mistral devstack jobs non-voting in Rocky

These jobs are problematic when trying to merge a security fix into
Rocky[1]. This change has passed and merged intro master, Train and
Stein. It even passed CI once in Rocky (on Nov 19th) but then failed
in the gate.

This change disables CI to allow this security fix to land and will
be reverted afterwards where we can investigate the unstable CI.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694733/

Change-Id: I26d587241f765b13e135be5c4cf90976903af9ea

commit_message:
Ceph Grafana should not be exposed by HAProxy as a public service

We need to set ceph_grafana_vip on a network which is routable
and yet not the public network where the OpenStack APIs are exposed
but the service is *not* public.

Change-Id: I7d636c4513317162ec4b49aa12d88a959bf5c537
(cherry picked from commit 1fc65d1d1b3f0f17457f6e121176c9fef65843b5)

commit_message:
Pin ceph dashboard containers on a specific tag

Since in OSP context we want to rely on more stable ceph dashboard
content, in this review we pin the grafana/prometheus/alertmanager
and node-exporter containers to a specific tag suggested by ceph
team.

Change-Id: I2b308dea3c9e2380185fd3cce68a3aad5842a730

subject: Catch "ValueError" exception in RpcJSONEncoder
messages:
[{'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-10-09 13:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-10-09 14:19:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hello

Thanks for this patch, can you explain to me how to reproduce this issue?'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-10-09 14:30:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Some commennts inline:'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-10-09 17:58:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Hi Hervé. Please check http://paste.openstack.org/show/782460/. You need to install neutron (from source if you want, or package).'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2019-10-09 18:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-10-09 18:31:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-10-09 18:33:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Rodolfo for the given example, I'll try to use it to make me a better opinion. Be back soon."}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-10-10 09:47:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-10-11 13:12:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

To give you a quick feedback I facing some difficulties to test through your given script.

For the moment I can't use it locally against my laptop or in any virtualenv and also against a fully deployed environment.

I facing lot of different issues not related with the problem described here, I guess to reproduce this it necessite specific conditions that I can't reach on my side with my envs."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-10-14 15:54:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I would be more comfortable modifying this (sensitive) code if we had a pretty good idea of why that error is thrown. I wonder if the "raise EOFError" in the same file and the whole eventlet workaround mentioned there do not have corner cases with recent versions of Python...'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-10-16 14:50:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-10-16 14:55:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> To give you a quick feedback I facing some difficulties to test
 > through your given script.
 > 
 > For the moment I can't use it locally against my laptop or in any
 > virtualenv and also against a fully deployed environment.
 > 
 > I facing lot of different issues not related with the problem
 > described here, I guess to reproduce this it necessite specific
 > conditions that I can't reach on my side with my envs.

Does it mean you don't see this error when executing a command not allowed? Do you see the expected error? You can run this on a VM with neutron installed.

This is the rootwrap.conf file I have (default one): http://paste.openstack.org/show/784106/

And an example of filter file, debug.filters (in /etc/neutron/rootwrap.d): http://paste.openstack.org/show/784107/"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-10-18 14:58:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's probably a corner case, as it should be caught in testing by https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/src/branch/master/oslo_rootwrap/tests/test_functional.py#L202 (daemon mode trying to execute executable that does not exist, before creating it and trying again)... So I'm not sure how to reproduce it.

I would not be against blindly fixing it by catching that exception (filtering for a specific message), but the problem is we don't even know if we should raise FilterMatchNotExecutable or NoFilterMatched. If we just pick one we would still produce an invalid error message in some cases.... so not a real improvement. Also I'm not sure how much Python promises those exception messages not to change over time.

For all those reasons I'd be much more comfortable fixing the root cause rather than working around it at the consumer layer."}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2019-10-23 14:06:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > To give you a quick feedback I facing some difficulties to test
 > > through your given script.
 > >
 > > For the moment I can't use it locally against my laptop or in any
 > > virtualenv and also against a fully deployed environment.
 > >
 > > I facing lot of different issues not related with the problem
 > > described here, I guess to reproduce this it necessite specific
 > > conditions that I can't reach on my side with my envs.
 > 
 > Does it mean you don't see this error when executing a command not
 > allowed? Do you see the expected error? You can run this on a VM
 > with neutron installed.
 > 

Yep that mean that I couldn't reproduced your scenario and I can't seen the expected error. I've tried to reproduce it against a fully deployed env so with neutron installed etc... with yours previous given instructions.

 > This is the rootwrap.conf file I have (default one):
 > http://paste.openstack.org/show/784106/
 > 
 > And an example of filter file, debug.filters (in /etc/neutron/rootwrap.d):
 > http://paste.openstack.org/show/784107/

Also I agreed with the Thierry comments:
- I'm not confortable too with this solution and to raising exceptions that we are not sure that it's the right ones. 
- It's more worth to try to fix the root cause instead of hide this through an exception."}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-11-21 09:08:59.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

As commented by Herve and Thierry, I need to review rootwrap code before proposing this patch. Let's go for it."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-09 13:23:58.000000000', 'message': 'Catch "ValueError" exception in RpcJSONEncoder

When command to be executed is not present in the filter files, a
"wrapper.NoFilterMatched" should be thrown.

Currently, maybe due to an error in "json" library, when a non
authorized command is evaluated in daemon mode, the following
exception is raised:
  ValueError("I/O operation on closed file")

In other to present a more understandable message to the user, this
exception is catched and "wrapper.NoFilterMatched" is passed instead.

Change-Id: I8e80b8995883151741c8f0e448c7881852a69f85
Closes-Bug: #1643457
'}]
commit_message:
Catch "ValueError" exception in RpcJSONEncoder

When command to be executed is not present in the filter files, a
"wrapper.NoFilterMatched" should be thrown.

Currently, maybe due to an error in "json" library, when a non
authorized command is evaluated in daemon mode, the following
exception is raised:
  ValueError("I/O operation on closed file")

In other to present a more understandable message to the user, this
exception is catched and "wrapper.NoFilterMatched" is passed instead.

Change-Id: I8e80b8995883151741c8f0e448c7881852a69f85
Closes-Bug: #1643457

commit_message:
Fix proportional autoscaler image

The proportional autoscaler was not taken from
the real gcr.io/google_containers but but from
docker.io/googlecontainer.

story: 2003993
task: 30492

Change-Id: I2b6fa6f6c839d86b935feb9e1fa9f044d1835b34

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Kuryr is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/
Change-Id: I6c14fa3b0c3a19b5f50f5d78a43ba060c10de914

commit_message:
Stop enforcing py2 requirements match starting with U

Ussuri and later will be Python 3 only. This updates our requirements
checks to only enforce local requirements match the exact global
requirements for the py3.5 and later entries.

Python 2 requirements can still be present in the local files, but this
allows teams that want to remove all Python 2 code to clean up their
requirements files for entries that are no longer relevant.

Change-Id: Ifaa44593b08630f84bb50060871412c66315adcc
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

explaining the change.

commit_message:
Try deinit odl_features in TestOdlFeaturesNoFixture setUpClass

test_feature_configs_does_not_mutate_default_features sporadically fails
with the following:
testtools.matchers._impl.MismatchError: {} !=
{'operational-port-status': '', 'bgpvpn-vni': ''}
This patch runs odl_features.deinit at the beginning of the test to run
it on a clean beases.

Change-Id: I2185c30f260f95ef2e0b90c14399260702837f29
Closes-Bug: #1835216

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-20 13:19:44.000000000', 'message': 'Only install python3 packages if necessary

In change I43de36ab570af40bc837d859568f5428c167f083, we started
installing the 'python3-' variants of the 'python-' packages installed
by the 'ceph-common' package in 'install_ceph_remote'. In that change,
we made the assertion that we didn't need to "both hiding this behind
the 'python3_enabled' function or 'USE_PYTHON3' variable since (a) these
packages can happily coexist, (b) projects should be switching to Python
3 now, and (c) using these would require sourcing additional, otherwise
unnecessary devstack libraries just to use this simple function".
However, this didn't take into account the fact that this plugin is not
versioned. This means *any* job that uses this plugin, including things
like stable/pike, will now attempt to install the 'python3-' packages.
Since the base OS on stable/pike, Xenial (16.04), doesn't actually
provide these 'python3-' variants, the command will always fail.

Start hiding the command behind a 'use_python3' function call. Hopefully
by time we drop Python 2 support here we won't have maintained branches
using Xenial. If we do, we'll need to branch or something like that.

Change-Id: I890a1e673fde212218eff4fcf82f7941b3283e5f
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1853280
'}]
commit_message:
Only install python3 packages if necessary

In change I43de36ab570af40bc837d859568f5428c167f083, we started
installing the 'python3-' variants of the 'python-' packages installed
by the 'ceph-common' package in 'install_ceph_remote'. In that change,
we made the assertion that we didn't need to "both hiding this behind
the 'python3_enabled' function or 'USE_PYTHON3' variable since (a) these
packages can happily coexist, (b) projects should be switching to Python
3 now, and (c) using these would require sourcing additional, otherwise
unnecessary devstack libraries just to use this simple function".
However, this didn't take into account the fact that this plugin is not
versioned. This means *any* job that uses this plugin, including things
like stable/pike, will now attempt to install the 'python3-' packages.
Since the base OS on stable/pike, Xenial (16.04), doesn't actually
provide these 'python3-' variants, the command will always fail.

Start hiding the command behind a 'use_python3' function call. Hopefully
by time we drop Python 2 support here we won't have maintained branches
using Xenial. If we do, we'll need to branch or something like that.

Change-Id: I890a1e673fde212218eff4fcf82f7941b3283e5f
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1853280

commit_message:
Remove containers before removing associated storage

We added --storage option in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/679793/
when removing containers with podman. However, it won't delete the exited
containers, i.e only orphaned storage would be removed with it.

So, we have to do both 'rm' and 'rm --storage' with podman to ensure
that we don't get the container name already used error,

Change-Id: I66ce37b19dd855e9798a7877494264f6a128d284
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/681989
Related-Bug: #1840691

Fix missing environment variable for Qinling

commit_message:
Fix error validate token when run cron trigger

A trust client can't do validate token when run cron trigger
This patch will fix that.

Change-Id: I793fbfec03032d9ff7137c11becb6d1c18ec54bc
Closes-Bug: #1843175
(cherry picked from commit 51b7dd0c6d5c4d0de354719765968ca883b9f8fb)

commit_message:
Set DB retry for quota_enforcement pecan_wsgi hook

The hook starts a DB transaction and should be covered with
DB retry decorator.

Closes-Bug: #1777965
Closes-Bug: #1771293
Change-Id: I044980a98845edc7b0a02e3323a1e62eb54c10c7

[{'created': '2019-11-20 07:46:56.000000000', 'message': "Ignore blacklisted nodes when rendering network config

We don't include nodes blacklisted with 'DeploymentServerBlacklist'
in 'ServerIdData' stack output, that is used to populate

commit_message:
Ignore blacklisted nodes when rendering network config

We don't include nodes blacklisted with 'DeploymentServerBlacklist'
in 'ServerIdData' stack output, that is used to populate
'server_roles' dict. Let's ignore writing NetworkConfig for those.

Change-Id: I837ed2dd7937a87055a8acff686ca3165dba3837
Closes-Bug: #1853247

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-08 00:06:29.000000000', 'message': 'Use wrapper class for NeutronFixture get_client

This addresses a NOTE/TODO from change
I3cf6eb4654663865d9258c38f05cd05974ffcf9d where the NeutronFixture is
storing "admin-ness" from the last get_client call and using it to
control the behavior of the list_ports method.

This adds a wrapper class that represents a Neutron client object and
stores a reference to a NeutronFixture in order to track admin-ness for
separate get_client calls.

While making this change, unused methods:
fake_get_instance_security_group_bindings and _get_first_id_match were
noticed in NeutronFixture, so they are removed.

Change-Id: I7aa05e857599db820d0fc4daeb730f2a40b3291c

commit_message:
Use wrapper class for NeutronFixture get_client

This addresses a NOTE/TODO from change
I3cf6eb4654663865d9258c38f05cd05974ffcf9d where the NeutronFixture is
storing "admin-ness" from the last get_client call and using it to
control the behavior of the list_ports method.

This adds a wrapper class that represents a Neutron client object and
stores a reference to a NeutronFixture in order to track admin-ness for
separate get_client calls.

While making this change, unused methods:
fake_get_instance_security_group_bindings and _get_first_id_match were
noticed in NeutronFixture, so they are removed.

Change-Id: I7aa05e857599db820d0fc4daeb730f2a40b3291c

commit_message:
Dynamic pollster system to support non-OpenStack APIs

The goal of this PR is to add the support for
non-OpenStack APIs into Ceilometer. An example of such
API is the RadosGW usage API.

Change-Id: If5e1c9bce9e2709746338e043b20d328d8fb4504

commit_message:
functional: Make '_wait_for_state_change' behave consistently

Both 'ServersTestBase' and 'InstanceHelperMixin' provide implementations
of '_wait_for_state_change' but they behave differently. The former
waits for an instance to transition *from* the provided state, while the
latter, somewhat more sanely, waits for the transition *to* the provided
state. Switch to using the latter everywhere and make the necessary
changes. Due to class hierarchies, we end up with two nearly identical
implementations but these will be merged in a future change.

Change-Id: I80cdc0a33ec27b1389130c22f9c3a8ff69f6b1a0
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Modify help for update host command

The old and new host should be provided in the particular format
host@backend#pool.
The pool is optional for the currenthost in single pool environment but
is recommended practice.

Change-Id: Ide28d6220eeb9d88423c3a0161301b3251035eab

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-38393 : SUCCESS in 2h 29m 22s'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-10-25 18:10:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

For some reason it took me some effort to wrap my head around this (could the commit message use some improving, perhaps?)

To rephrase what's going on:

We want ServerBase to inherit from InstanceHelperMixin. They both have implementations of a "wait until server is deleted" function - ServerBase's is called _wait_for_deletion and takes a server_id, InstanceHelperMixin's is called _wait_until_deleted and takes a full server JSON-y dict. [1] will rename the ServersTestBase's version to bring it inline with InstanceHelperMixin's version.

The thing is, ServerBase's _delete_server currently calls _wait_for_deletion and passes it a server_id. As such, _delete_server itself is only passed a server_id. After [1], this server_id will no longer be enough, as _delete_server will need to call the newly merged _wait_until_deleted that takes a full server JSON-y dict, so _delete_server itself needs to receive a full server JSON-y dict.

*This* is what this patch does: makes _delete_server receive a full server JSON-y dict.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/689181/3/nova/tests/functional/test_servers.py'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-11-14 11:26:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

 > server JSON-y dict.

commit_message:
functional: Rework '_delete_server'

We want 'ServerBase' to inherit from 'InstanceHelperMixin'. They both
have implementations of a "wait until server is deleted" function.  The
'ServerBase' implementation is called '_wait_for_deletion' and takes a
'server_id', while the 'InstanceHelperMixin' implementation is called
'_wait_until_deleted' and takes a full server JSON-y dict. A later
change, I0c56841d098d3e9d72db65be3143f3c893f0b6ba, will rework the
'ServersTestBase' version to bring it inline with 'InstanceHelperMixin'
version. However, 'ServerBase._delete_server' currently calls a
'_wait_for_deletion' function and passes it a 'server_id'. As such,
'_delete_server' itself is only passed a server_id. After the future
change, this 'server_id' will no longer be enough as '_delete_server'
will need to call the newly merged '_wait_until_deleted' that takes a
full server JSON-y dict, so '_delete_server' itself needs to receive a
full server JSON-y dict.

Do this work now to simplify the future patch.

Change-Id: Iceafa5ff2b7abff7c6d974ba49036ef03fb1c85f
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Migrate from with_X loop.

With the release of Ansible 2.5, the recommended way to perform
 loops is the use the new loop keyword instead of with_X style loops.
This review addresses aforementioned change for common tasks
within tripleo-upgrade role.

Change-Id: I70d387b381b6ce297507cbfe669ea7be902df605
(cherry picked from commit b25817a233bcb5f836319cce10bb04bbb732c4f7)

commit_message:
Switch to more specific include modules for ffwd.

Include has some unintuitive behaviours depending on
if it is running in a static or dynamic in play or in playbook context,
in an effort to clarify behaviours move to a new set of modules:
  include_tasks, include_role, import_playbook, import_tasks.

Change-Id: I32198527a084d35f8a2c91e3e7d3f32b6fbe9e1e
(cherry picked from commit d67e6e7166d7d554b27763cf0c253737f4a189e5)

if it is running in a static or dynamic in play or in playbook context,

As part of community goal of dropping py27 support[1], we are
moving the devstack to py3 by default[2]. That will make grenade job

To avoid existing grenade py2 job break, this commit moves grenade

Change-Id: I4d0468cbae30d44c63d5bdd260414ee3659bec61
'}]
commit_message:
Migrate grenade jobs to py3

As part of community goal of dropping py27 support[1], we are
moving the devstack to py3 by default[2]. That will make grenade job
to perform upgrade from py2 to py3 which will not work.

To avoid existing grenade py2 job break, this commit moves grenade
jobs to py3 which is what we planned as part dropping the py2 support.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649097/12
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010938.html

Change-Id: I4d0468cbae30d44c63d5bdd260414ee3659bec61

Switch to more specific include modules for upgrades.

Include has some unintuitive behaviours depending on
if it is running in a static or dynamic in play or in playbook context,
in an effort to clarify behaviours move to a new set of modules:

commit_message:
Switch to more specific include statements.

Include has some unintuitive behaviours depending on if it is running
in a static or dynamic in play or in playbook context,
in an effort to clarify behaviours we are moving to a new set modules:
 include_tasks, include_role, import_playbook, import_tasks.
Also this one might got deprecated so let switch to more specific
 modules from generic.

Note this change also include a fix for the invalid option option to
include_tasks that was not needed at the time of the original commit.

Closes-Bug: #1827906

Change-Id: Ib7ec62a4e8311c4da2af85e30eb33184d05a046f
(cherry picked from commit 2ff51bd816fae612611f8d0f1163f15447ddf1aa)

commit_message:
Fix error validate token when run cron trigger

A trust client can't do validate token when run cron trigger
This patch will fix that.

Change-Id: I793fbfec03032d9ff7137c11becb6d1c18ec54bc
Closes-Bug: #1843175

commit_message:
Remove Floating IP DNS record upon associated port deletion

Port deletion triggers disassociate_floatingips. This patch ensures
that method not only clears the port association for a Floating IP,
but also removes any DNS record associated with it.

Change-Id: Ia6202610c09811f240af35e2523126447bf02ca5
Closes-Bug: #1812168
(cherry picked from commit 4379310846078c45df140071688f740cd900c1d6)

In addition, networking-ovn jobs running against ovs master require python3 as python2 support was removed from the ovs tree. If USE_PYTHON3 != True, then the OVS build will fail due to the 'six' library not being found for python3 during ./configure.

Also, centos7 minimal doesn't install python3, so we need to ensure that python3/python3-devel are installed before continuing. I've attempted to fix those issues here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/688799/ and hopefully that will fix the devstack-platform-centos-7 issue if you rebased off of it (assuming I didn't break a bunch of other stuff) ;)"}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-10-15 20:49:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

re: running pip 19.2.3, it looks like that is happening because we are running pip from the tempest tox venv at that point?'}, {'account_id': 11952, 'date': '2019-10-15 22:27:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-10-16 09:46:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I think what's happening on the "old" side of the grenade run is that devstack is skipping to install the capped pip3 because USE_PYTHON3 is false there.

https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/src/branch/master/tools/install_pip.sh#L93-L95

Maybe we should change that to always install the capped pip3? Would have to happen in stable/train.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-10-16 09:50:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

We also need to fix the error on centos before this can proceed.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-10-16 09:54:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Change USE_PYTHON3=True by default

Since Stein, gate jobs have been using bionic nodes so they
are running with python 3.6, so it makes sense to also default
devstack itself to run with python3 by default.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/688731

Change-Id: I52b03caee0ba700da3a15035201ea6cd91baa06b

commit_message:
TestMinBwQoSOvs must call the correct methods

Minimum bandwidth rules and policies set in OVS can be found using
the methods:
  - OVSBridge._find_qos()
  - OVSBridge._find_queue(port_id)

The methods currently used are incorrect and are not testing correctly
the real status of the OVS DB.

Change-Id: Ibf2b06439a3cf6a40fec0435b4305a93a5629fd8
Closes-Bug: #1848220
(cherry picked from commit 59b37701e9e0f07583e92c69537b78e696360997)
(cherry picked from commit 5c50ead96dd1deec97875a137783d5c4f405195b)

commit_message:
Handle localrc early enough in stackrc

We need to source the environment overrides before they get evaluated.
Otherwise e.g. USE_PYTHON3 is factually being ignored for some settings.

Also fix creating python3 venvs by using the "virtualenv" command for
that task.

Change-Id: I16c78a7fef80372d9a1684c3256c5b50b052ecae
