commit_message:
Ensure correct failure message is checked on CRD validation

The error message retuned when a CRD is not validated has changed
on Kubernetes 1.16. We should also update the NP and Namespaces
tempests tests to match it, as the gate is using Kubernetes 1.16.

Change-Id: I4ed2bdbbc664579689763f2759741b0efced6db6

subject: Finalise the transition of the docs team to a SIG
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 7198, 'name': 'Jay Bryant', 'email': 'jungleboyj@electronicjungle.net', 'username': 'jsbryant'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10343, 'name': 'Jim Rollenhagen', 'email': 'jim@jimrollenhagen.com', 'username': 'jimrollenhagen'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 12404, 'name': 'Rico Lin', 'email': 'ricolin@ricolky.com', 'username': 'rico.lin'}, {'_account_id': 12898, 'name': 'Tony Breeds', 'email': 'tony@bakeyournoodle.com', 'username': 'tonyb'}, {'_account_id': 13995, 'name': 'Nate Johnston', 'email': 'nate.johnston@redhat.com', 'username': 'natejohnston'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 16708, 'name': 'Kendall Nelson', 'display_name': 'Kendall (diablo_rojo)', 'email': 'kennelson11@gmail.com', 'username': 'kjnelson'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 27068, 'name': 'Trinh Nguyen', 'email': 'dangtrinhnt@gmail.com', 'username': 'dangtrinhnt'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-05-04 17:24:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-06 20:44:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

There was some discussion of this at the summit/PTG last week. I think Thierry's position is that teams should be "integral to producing the software", and that definition makes sense to me. I think given the relatively sparse activity of the documentation team, and the fact that the install and user guides are now owned by each project team, the documentation team as it stands today is no longer "integral" except in one regard: the docs.openstack.org web site.

So, I would prefer to find a new home for the web site content on a project team instead of moving it to the SIG. The remaining content could be moved to the new SIG, but I think we need the web site to stay part of a project team. Perhaps the release team?

This is a big change, so we should also have a mailing list thread documenting the discussion linked from this change (and the previous ones, if you want, although those are less "controversial" aspects).'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-05-09 15:39:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes -- Project teams are about producing the OpenStack software release. Work can be done in code project teams (Nova), or in development support (Infra, QA), or in dependency/release management (Release Management, Requirements). All this work sits upstream of the release. None of it is a "special interest" -- they all participate and are integral to the production of the software release.

Documentation is, imho, a part of a release. So a team producing the openstack documentation (or maintaining the documentation production tooling) should stay as an openstack project team.

That said, if the tooling is maintained as part of Oslo, and the components docs are maintained by each project team, then I'd say that the Docs project team might be better served by a "Documentation" or "Technical Writers" SIG that would serve as a guild of people specifically interested in upping the quality of our technical documentation overall.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-13 10:07:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree with both Doug and Thierry comments.
Extra reply, on Doug's comment: I am not sure about the fact to add this to release team though."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-05-16 08:54:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Frankly I'm a little saddened by Docs become a SIG, I understand but still it seems like generally the wrong direction to me.

However that isn't the point here, assuming that is going to happen ... I agree with Doug that openstack-manuals needs to stay associated with a project team rather than SIG.

While none is a great fit I think Release Management is probably the least worst place for it to land.  It will mean learning new tools and process but I think the Release team can do it (esp. if we can convince the existing core team to help [or better yet stay around] :))"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-05-16 09:17:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

For the openstack-manuals corner case, I'm a bit worried to add a completely different skillset to the release team. I'm wondering if it would not be simpler to consider the docs website is done downstream of the software produced upstream (more as a compilation of content produced upstream) and can be owned by the Docs SIG."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-16 11:17:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> For the openstack-manuals corner case, I'm a bit worried to add a
 > completely different skillset to the release team. I'm wondering if
 > it would not be simpler to consider the docs website is done
 > downstream of the software produced upstream (more as a compilation
 > of content produced upstream) and can be owned by the Docs SIG.

Agreed with Thierry. Being SIG doesn't prevent owning repositories afaik :)"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-16 13:38:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> For the openstack-manuals corner case, I'm a bit worried to add a
 > completely different skillset to the release team. I'm wondering if
 > it would not be simpler to consider the docs website is done
 > downstream of the software produced upstream (more as a compilation
 > of content produced upstream) and can be owned by the Docs SIG.

My main concern is that it isn't clear converting the Docs group from team to SIG is going to produce additional contributors. There is also the fact that updating the site is currently listed as a step in the release process (step 12 of https://releases.openstack.org/reference/process.html#between-rc1-and-final ), which makes it feel like it is part of producing the software.

Maintaining the site isn't especially hard, and it's pretty well documented. But I think we want someone clearly signed up to do it rather than leaving it to chance. If the release team isn't the right group, maybe we should just pull it into the TC's list of repos until someone else shows more interest?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-16 20:17:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Since there was some confusion today on IRC, I want to more clearly and fully state my position.

I like turning documentation support into a SIG.

I'm happy that the Oslo team is willing to take over maintenance of the tools currently owned by the documentation team.

I think we should find a team to take over the docs.openstack.org web site portion of the openstack-manuals repository.

I think all of the other documentation content in openstack-manuals should move over to the new SIG.

So, my only objection on this patch is the change in ownership of openstack-manuals and that is only because of the need to update docs.openstack.org as part of the release process every cycle."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-05-17 13:02:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't have a strong opinion either way. Happy to follow Doug's lead on that."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-22 13:51:40.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from docs-project-to-sig to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:49:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:51:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:55:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-06-28 17:20:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-06-28 17:21:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

rebased to place it in series with the previous patch'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-06-28 17:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from 657142 to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-19 13:54:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Email has been sent regarding ownership of docs.openstack.org. Please see: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-August/008571.html

Thank you'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-22 10:20:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

There is apparently still some confusion around the "Docs SIG" name...

SIGs are groups of people with a common (special) interest. The difference with a project team is that project teams produce deliverables that form OpenStack releases.

Documentation for each component is clearly a part of OpenStack releases, but the Docs team is no longer in charge of producing that. At this point, the Docs team is more a group of technical writers maintaining guidelines, tooling and best practices for *project teams* to produce good documentation.

As such, the Docs team is definitely fitting the "SIG" group concept -- a group of people with a shared, special interest (technical writing), pushing common objectives (upholding high quality standards in OpenStack documentation). But calling it the "Docs SIG" makes it look like we don't consider "Docs" to be an integral part of the OpenStack software releases, which is not true.

I wonder if calling it the "Technical Writing SIG" would not make it clearer what the group is about, who should join it, and why it's not directly in charge of producing all the docs.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-03 09:30:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> There is apparently still some confusion around the "Docs SIG"
 > name...
 > 
 > SIGs are groups of people with a common (special) interest. The
 > difference with a project team is that project teams produce
 > deliverables that form OpenStack releases.
 > 
 > Documentation for each component is clearly a part of OpenStack
 > releases, but the Docs team is no longer in charge of producing
 > that. At this point, the Docs team is more a group of technical
 > writers maintaining guidelines, tooling and best practices for
 > *project teams* to produce good documentation.
 > 
 > As such, the Docs team is definitely fitting the "SIG" group
 > concept -- a group of people with a shared, special interest
 > (technical writing), pushing common objectives (upholding high
 > quality standards in OpenStack documentation). But calling it the
 > "Docs SIG" makes it look like we don't consider "Docs" to be an
 > integral part of the OpenStack software releases, which is not
 > true.
 > 
 > I wonder if calling it the "Technical Writing SIG" would not make
 > it clearer what the group is about, who should join it, and why
 > it's not directly in charge of producing all the docs.

I think that's a great idea, Thierry.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-03 09:39:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-03 09:50:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-03 09:51:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-03 09:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Published edit on patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-10-03 10:19:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 27068, 'date': '2019-10-03 14:32:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Finalise the transition of the docs team to a SIG

The documentation team is officially being disbanded as
an official project team in favor of a SIG. A "SIG" is a group
of people with a shared, special interest, pushing common
objectives. This review moves the remaining docs to deliverables
of the newly formed Technical Writing SIG.

The docs team has been a group of technical contributors
maintaining guidelines, tooling, and best practices for
the project teams whilst the project teams have been responsible
for producing documentation for each component since the Pike
release.

Whilst documentation is still considered imperative to an OpenStack
release, the docs team is no longer in charge of producing the
product documentation and therefore should be disbanded in favor
of a SIG to reflect their current working model in an official
capacity.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/691277/
Change-Id: I1c47c7d09b0ef89b7d737b0a29b828fbbf9e141a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Alexandra Settle <asettle@suse.com>

subject: Turn PowerVMStackers team into a SIG

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-05 14:58:28.000000000', 'message': 'remove powervmstackers team

Following the U cycle election there was no candidate for the
powervmstackers team PTL role. This is the second cycle in a row where
that problem has occurred, which indicates that the team is not active
in the community. This patch removes the team from TC governance, but
does not deprecate the code they are managing.

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tc/2019/tc.2019-09-05-14.00.log.html#l-148

Change-Id: I8cd460ece1b80332386ae41c63970644c4169615
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-09-05 15:00:03.000000000', 'message': 'remove powervmstackers team

Following the U cycle election there was no candidate for the
powervmstackers team PTL role. This is the second cycle in a row where
that problem has occurred, which indicates that the team is not active
in the community. This patch removes the team from TC governance, but
does not deprecate the code they are managing.

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tc/2019/tc.2019-09-05-14.00.log.html#l-148
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-September/009127.html

Change-Id: I8cd460ece1b80332386ae41c63970644c4169615
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-10-17 10:29:40.000000000', 'message': 'Turn PowerVMStackers team into a SIG

For the U cycle election there was no candidate for the powervmstackers
team PTL role. This is the second cycle in a row where that problem has
occurred, which indicates that the team has trouble keeping up with the
requirements placed on OpenStack project teams.

A Special Interest Group matches the work of the PowerVMStackers team
better. It places less constraints on the team deliverables, and might
attract more people interested in better support of PowerVM in
OpenStack, which is arguably a special interest.

This patch removes the project team, and moves their code repositories
to be owned by the newly-created PowerVM SIG. That way, PowerVM
contributors remain ATCs and can continue voting for TC election.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Signed-off-by: Thierry Carrez <thierry@openstack.org>

commit_message:
Turn PowerVMStackers team into a SIG

For the U cycle election there was no candidate for the powervmstackers
team PTL role. This is the second cycle in a row where that problem has
occurred, which indicates that the team has trouble keeping up with the
requirements placed on OpenStack project teams.

A Special Interest Group matches the work of the PowerVMStackers team
better. It places less constraints on the team deliverables, and might
attract more people interested in better support of PowerVM in
OpenStack, which is arguably a special interest.

This patch removes the project team, and moves their code repositories
to be owned by the newly-created PowerVMStackers SIG. That way,
PowerVMStackers remain ATCs and can continue voting for TC election.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Signed-off-by: Thierry Carrez <thierry@openstack.org>

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/689119
Change-Id: I8cd460ece1b80332386ae41c63970644c4169615

commit_message:
Add rhel8 to supported systems

I guess it's not enough to make it work, but this is just to start work
on adding CentOS 8 gate to kuryr-kubernetes. Let's see what else will
break.

Change-Id: I496d01c664818456742d4de06494382b238b2a1c

commit_message:
Create PowerVMStackers SIG

Create a PowerVMStackers SIG to replace the PowerVMStackers project
team. They are working on several repositories adding support for
PowerVM in various OpenStack projects (nova, neutron, ceilometer) but
those have not been adopted by those consuming teams yet.

A SIG would better fit the needs of those interested in better support
for PowerVM and the POWER CPU architecture on OpenStack, and put less
synchronized release constraints (and PTL election issues) on the group.

Change-Id: I584ade1afe22a51f77caef489fdf57deff4662ea
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/680438/

commit_message:
Make mask_dict_password case insensitive and add new patterns

In Icc19b7c8bdb6a3182939d5e9fdef21288b19f43d mask_password was made case
insensitive but mask_dict_password wasn't. This update makes the
behaviour of these functions the same.

Instead of lowering _SANITIZE_KEYS each time the source list is lowered.

New password patterns from realworld logs were added to the patterns.

Change-Id: Ic3ee301857630a15b9c26fd5d0fc907c43199517
Related-Bug: #1850843

commit_message:
Remove unused path variable from promote secrets

The promote jobs do not use "path", they use "docs...path" instead,
remove the extra unused variable.

Change-Id: I57deeadfef3234eecb3f637a6f41701dba4631c6

commit_message:
Ensure `isolinux.bin` is present and configured in devstack

When devstack boots a node over virtual media in BIOS boot mode,
`isolinux.bin` boot loader needs to be present for grilling hybrid
ISO images.

This patch makes devstack pulling necessary packages and configure
ironic accordingly.

Change-Id: I2f4e582aa05fc54610a4c43695124219714368c2

commit_message:
Explicit mention py2 for neutron-grenade job

Devstack is moving to py3 by default[1] and neutron-grenade
will fail. There are patches up to drop the neutron-grenade
job but those are not merged yet.

let's keep this job runnable by explicitly mention the py2
and dropping plan will continue as it is.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-November/010938.html

Change-Id: I086b5eee710b80e95703abb46a076aff5b7741f2

commit_message:
Drop old neutron-grenade job

This job is still running python 2.7. As we are dropping py2 support in
Ussuri cycle, lets drop this job now.
There is same job called "grenade-py3" which runs on python 3 already
and this will be now used in project's CI.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695036/

Change-Id: I5cd8e137a3ae06e49a4351629c5eb207c4e6bf1a

[{'created': '2019-11-18 17:57:49.000000000', 'message': 'Fix listeners with SNI certificates

The single process patch changed the way listeners and load balancers
are deployed inside the amphora. This caused listeners with SNI
enabled to load all of the certificates for all of the TLS enabled
listeners on a load balancer.
This patch corrects that by configuring each listener with a
specific list of certificates.

Change-Id: I2f3c7ab4137dbd84d77a6a6b675975af406249d0
Story: 2006758
Task: 37252
(cherry picked from commit 3c05ce1297492ad1346ace3377f700c062e628da)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix listeners with SNI certificates

The single process patch changed the way listeners and load balancers
are deployed inside the amphora. This caused listeners with SNI
enabled to load all of the certificates for all of the TLS enabled
listeners on a load balancer.
This patch corrects that by configuring each listener with a
specific list of certificates.

Change-Id: I2f3c7ab4137dbd84d77a6a6b675975af406249d0
Story: 2006758
Task: 37252
(cherry picked from commit 3c05ce1297492ad1346ace3377f700c062e628da)

commit_message:
Remove functional test specific nova code

There is a bug in oslo messaging fake RPC driver bug 1529084. This
driver is used in the nova functional test and the bug currently worked
around in the nova production code.

As the bug 1529084 is fixed now in oslo.messaging 10.3.0 we can remove
the workaround in the nova code by bumping the minimum version of
oslo.messaging.

Change-Id: I4a32a688c7ceb05c263a0e93a91fb9b8ff0c65d4
Related-Bug: #1529084

commit_message:
Remove fwaas_v1 exceptions and definitions

There are still fwaas_v1 exceptions and definitions in
neutron-lib, it is necessary to remove them because the
fwaas_v1 code has been removed in the Stein cycle[1] and
the related extensions will be removed.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/616410/
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692094/
Change-Id: Ibfc6dab327c9df59222cda3e6a1f5dc566aa1bde
Closes-bug: #1850602

commit_message:
Refactoring the codes about getting used and free resources

We have provided functions to get used and free resources in
class ModelRoot. So strategies can invoke the functions to
get used and free resources.

Change-Id: I3c74d56539ac6c6eb16b0d254a76260bc791567c

commit_message:
tox: Keeping going with docs

Sphinx 1.8 introduced [1] the '--keep-going' argument which, as its name
suggests, keeps the build running when it encounters non-fatal errors.
This is exceptionally useful in avoiding a continuous edit-build loop
when undertaking large doc reworks where multiple errors may be
introduced.

[1] https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/commit/e3483e9b045

Change-Id: Ie373018aafc05f7ea859a73c55163840dee60b56

commit_message:
Stop testing python2.7

Train was the last release supporting python2. Let's rip the bandaid
off.

Reference:
[1]. https://review.opendev.org/#/c/691365
[2]. https://review.opendev.org/#/c/688593

Change-Id: Ic4dffd12b96689709f6dcebf608d034242df7701

commit_message:
Microversion 2.79: Add delete_on_termination to volume-attach API

Added ``--disable-delete-on-termination`` and
``--enable-delete-on-termination`` options to the
``openstack server add volume`` command that enables users to mark
whether to delete the attached volume when the server is destroyed.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681267/

Part of blueprint support-delete-on-termination-in-server-attach-volume

Change-Id: I6b5cd54b82a1135335a71b9768a1a2c2012f755b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-07 21:08:09.000000000', 'message': "Make designate reproducible

I'm forwarding the patch against the Debian package at:
https://bugs.debian.org/942848

Whilst working on the Reproducible Builds effort [0] we noticed
that designate could not be built reproducibly.

This is because it embeds the absolute build path in the sample
configuration. Patch attached that uses oslo-config's sample_default
instead.

 [0] https://reproducible-builds.org/

Change-Id: I605bbdfe7d0b734b31cdf85691f8c6d3850fc8c7
"}]
commit_message:
Make designate reproducible

I'm forwarding the patch against the Debian package at:
https://bugs.debian.org/942848

Whilst working on the Reproducible Builds effort [0] we noticed
that designate could not be built reproducibly.

This is because it embeds the absolute build path in the sample
configuration. Patch attached that uses oslo-config's sample_default
instead.

 [0] https://reproducible-builds.org/

Change-Id: I605bbdfe7d0b734b31cdf85691f8c6d3850fc8c7

commit_message:
[ceph-osd] Separate ceph-disk based deployment scripts

This is to create a different folder for ceph-disk based deplyoments
so that it will be easy to maintain when we introduce ceph-volume.

Separate folder for both the tools gives us flexibilty to develop or
fix the issues and commit the code to respective folders without breaking
other tool-based deployments.

Change-Id: Ib0099d292a8692dc6676eb5ed624d5d1ef677cfe

Found a bug'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-11-14 18:30:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-11-14 18:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6737, 'date': '2019-11-14 19:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-11-14 22:58:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19: -Code-Review

There is still one corner case that could spark some confusion on users: for the config option max-ttl that is used when creating the CA and when updating the max-lease-ttl, if that config is updated, the max-lease-ttl is updated in vault, but the CA's max-ttl isn't. To update the CA's max-ttl the roles need to be updated.

During my testing, the max-lease-ttl didn't show any meaning when issuing certs (perhaps I could be missing something). I tested the following scenarios:

1) role max-ttl=50h, max-lease-ttl=40h, default-lease-ttl=30h. If I issue a cert without params, the TTL is 30h. If I specify 100h as the TTL, it caps at 50h.

2) same as above, but role max-ttl=40h and max-lease-ttl=50h. It caps at 40h. I don't see the use of max-lease-ttl for generating certs.

Given that max-lease-ttl fails to set a cap, a user may be confused by setting this config later and still being able to issue certs with up to 10 years TTL (max-ttl's default). Otherwise, all settings work correctly and make meaningful changes even after the CA is created. Therefore I think it is useful to update the role according to the value of max-ttl on config-changed hooks.

I will upload a patch soon after my last round of testing on a fresh deployment."}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-11-15 00:15:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-11-15 00:37:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

commit_message:
Make cert and ca cert ttl configurable

Currently the default ttl for a cert is not configurable
and defaults to one month. This patch makes the ttl
configurable and updates the default for new and
re-generated certs to 1 year and 10 years for the CA
cert.

Closes-Bug: #1841138

Change-Id: Iaa6709c74d64c4191b44b92d4cfb3a3dbbb3fdc8

[{'created': '2019-11-19 05:25:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix ssh_known_hosts hostname entries

The tripleo-ssh-known-hosts ansible role used the list of network names to
create the different possible hostnames in the ssh_known_hosts file. The
network names do not match the actual network hostnames, like internal_api
vs. internalapi which results in ssh host verification to fail and e.g. live
migration to fail.

Initial approach in a5bcbc8d015b792b3546ecbb139506f248dacfe8 had to be reverted
as it resulted in errors when the _hostname inventory information was missing
from the ansible inventory.

Also syncs to use the same approach to create the hostname like in
https://review.opendev.org/693010 to have entries in /etc/hosts and
ssh_known_hosts created in the same way/source.

Closes-Bug: #1852064

Change-Id: Ie04d0f0cd9474070bffd153fa3dddee9f304a14f
(cherry picked from commit d6541e624e6c98de12f3d04e659349c6aea69891)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ssh_known_hosts hostname entries

The tripleo-ssh-known-hosts ansible role used the list of network names to
create the different possible hostnames in the ssh_known_hosts file. The
network names do not match the actual network hostnames, like internal_api
vs. internalapi which results in ssh host verification to fail and e.g. live
migration to fail.

Initial approach in a5bcbc8d015b792b3546ecbb139506f248dacfe8 had to be reverted
as it resulted in errors when the _hostname inventory information was missing
from the ansible inventory.

Also syncs to use the same approach to create the hostname like in
https://review.opendev.org/693010 to have entries in /etc/hosts and
ssh_known_hosts created in the same way/source.

Closes-Bug: #1852064

Change-Id: Ie04d0f0cd9474070bffd153fa3dddee9f304a14f
(cherry picked from commit d6541e624e6c98de12f3d04e659349c6aea69891)

[{'created': '2019-11-13 01:09:52.000000000', 'message': 'Remove deprecated api service

The API service for Ceilometer was deprecated in Ocata [1] and apparently we
missed that. This removes all references to the API service which is no longer
needed.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/ceilometer/ocata.html#deprecation-notes

Change-Id: I7a888a4aaadaa8213d6763854b39d78910fad0db
Signed-off-by: Lance Albertson <lance@osuosl.org>

commit_message:
Remove deprecated api service

The API service for Ceilometer was deprecated in Ocata [1] and apparently we
missed that. This removes all references to the API service which is no longer
needed.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/ceilometer/ocata.html#deprecation-notes

Change-Id: I7a888a4aaadaa8213d6763854b39d78910fad0db
Signed-off-by: Lance Albertson <lance@osuosl.org>

commit_message:
Manage /etc/ceilometer/polling.yaml

This adds management of /etc/ceilometer/polling.yaml which defines which metrics
to poll and how often. This pulls in the default configuration which the same
for both RHEL and Ubuntu and adds two new attributes for configuring the file.

In addition, restart various services related to the configuration file.

Change-Id: I69ed0a8933a971d9cac20dbd4133197a7e4274af
Signed-off-by: Lance Albertson <lance@osuosl.org>

commit_message:
Fix Python 3 compatibility in network policy tests

In Python 3 {}.keys() return a view, not a list, so we cannot index it.
This commit fixes test_update_network_policy to anticipate that.

Change-Id: Idb6adec1d4b4b4a0f3c65b03c157f5fbb1c278de

commit_message:
FUP to Ie1a0cbd82a617dbcc15729647218ac3e9cd0e5a9

Mention that nova-grenade-multinode and nova-live-migration
run under python 3 in the job description since it's not
obvious from the job names.

Change-Id: I86f56b0238c72d2784e62f199cfc7704b95bbcf2

commit_message:
Fix driver tests on Windows

Driver tests were unable to run on Windows due to some import
errors.

Specifically, the 'setUp' method of the 'PoisonFunctions'
class would import 'nova.virt.libvirt' which in turn would cause
an error when running the Windows tests.

This change fixes this issue.

Partial-Bug: #1736395

Change-Id: Id21a24257ec1e00a1eb942aec725ae76e9f6e688

commit_message:
Start README.rst with a better title

Now that we are using gitea the contents of our README.rst are
more prominently displayed. Starting it with a "Team and repository
tags" title is a bit confusing. This change makes it start with the
name of the project instead.

Change-Id: Iaf6c162b26a32d16a083aa721aa084807af8cd60

commit_message:
Drop broken legacy job from devstack

The legacy-devstack-dsvm-updown runs with python2 and is thus now
failing with nova requiring py3. Since it only runs on master, we can
drop it completely.

Change-Id: I43088b5a79906377ce87cb9e7139096e2660a5d2

commit_message:
Add custom SSL CA Cert support for api.cinder.get_microversion

api.cinder.get_microversion function now supports OPENSTACK_SSL_NO_VERIFY
and OPENSTACK_SSL_CACERT config options.

This depends on commit 4a3a2c3c9a89ccff4e64d3da96de5b0af4303840 in
python-cinderclient, so the minimum version of python-cinderclient
is bumped to 5.0.0.

NOTE(amotoki): The stretegy of backporting to stable branches needs
a discussion with the requirements team as we cannot bump the
minimum version (at least the major version bump is surprising).

Change-Id: I22c6c60e10d8e9328f7f1e0c24d6c74496ec1a71
Closes-Bug: 1744670

commit_message:
WIP: neutron: avoid redundant show_network calls in _get_physnet_tunneled_info

When building the network vif info model for an instance we already
build the list of networks for the ports associated with the server
and have the network match available for the port when calling
_get_physnet_tunneled_info from _nw_info_build_network (the detailed
call trace information is in the bug report).

This change leverages that network dict and passes it to
_get_physnet_tunneled_info to avoid redundant show_network calls
in that method.

TODOs are left in place for similar inefficiencies in the
create_resource_request method. test_rebuild_server_with_network_affinity
also shows that _get_physnet_tunneled_info gets called with network
dicts that don't come from neutron but rather built from the info
cache which are missing fields (not using dict.get() everywhere would
have made this more obvious). As a result the method has to determine
if the network it's using is from neutron or not based on the
revision_number field.

Change-Id: I68075717ae393d94683c1595252c62bbecccd703
Closes-Bug: #1838817

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-24 17:32:19.000000000', 'message': 'Chunk BDM queries from ImageCacheManager._list_running_instances()

Change I74864b398f2d17a24b9ed676945183401e9872a0 in Newton
made the ImageCacheManager._list_running_instances() method do
a single query to get all BDMs for the list of instances rather
than one query per instance to avoid storming conductor.

However, when running nova-compute with shared storage on the
[DEFAULT]/instances_path config option or with a clustered
hypervisor (vCenter), the number of instances to process could
be large which can timeout the query to get BDMs (the message query
to conductor times out after 60 seconds by default because of
the rpc_response_timeout config option).

This change chunks the BDM queries to groups of 50 instances
per query to avoid overloading conductor but also complete before
the rpc_response_timeout.

We could further optimize this code to only query swap BDMs, but
that requires changes to the RPC versioned BlockDeviceMappingList
interface and cannot be backported, so that change needs to be
made separately.

While in here, the image_cache_manager_interval configuration
option help is updated to (1) fix formatting on possible values,
(2) describe the "large number of instances" scenarios to watch
out for, (3) add related options and (4) clarify the "0" default
interval value so it is not confused with the 2400 default.

Change-Id: I46a9ab5a8c017509c41b788c2448c4b4bb575c7f
Closes-Bug: #1804262
'}, {'created': '2019-01-24 17:37:17.000000000', 'message': 'Chunk BDM queries from ImageCacheManager._list_running_instances()

the rpc_response_timeout.

We could further optimize this code to only query swap BDMs, but
that requires changes to the RPC versioned BlockDeviceMappingList
interface and cannot be backported, so that change needs to be
made separately.

While in here, the image_cache_manager_interval configuration
option help is updated to (1) fix formatting on possible values,
(2) describe the "large number of instances" scenarios to watch
out for, (3) add related options and (4) clarify the "0" default

commit_message:
Chunk BDM queries from ImageCacheManager._list_running_instances()

Change I74864b398f2d17a24b9ed676945183401e9872a0 in Newton
made the ImageCacheManager._list_running_instances() method do
a single query to get all BDMs for the list of instances rather
than one query per instance to avoid storming conductor.

However, when running nova-compute with shared storage on the
[DEFAULT]/instances_path config option or with a clustered
hypervisor (vCenter), the number of instances to process could
be large which can timeout the query to get BDMs (the message query
to conductor times out after 60 seconds by default because of
the rpc_response_timeout config option).

This change chunks the BDM queries to groups of 50 instances
per query to avoid overloading conductor but also complete before
the rpc_response_timeout.

We could further optimize this code to only query swap BDMs, but
that requires changes to the RPC versioned BlockDeviceMappingList
interface and cannot be backported, so that change needs to be
made separately.

While in here, the image_cache_manager_interval configuration
option help is updated to (1) fix formatting on possible values,
(2) describe the "large number of instances" scenarios to watch
out for, (3) add related options and (4) clarify the "0" default
interval value so it is not confused with the 2400 default.

Change-Id: I46a9ab5a8c017509c41b788c2448c4b4bb575c7f
Closes-Bug: #1804262

commit_message:
Add the Octavia log offload parameters

This patch add the following new parameters for Octavia:

1. OctaviaAdminLogTargets
2. OctaviaAdminLogFacility
3. OctaviaForwardAllLogs
4. OctaviaTenantLogTargets
5. OctaviaTenantLogFacility
6. OctaviaUserLogFormat
7. OctaviaDisableLocalLogStorage

The default values mirror the Octavia service default values.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/683690
Change-Id: I46709b5e6cadab0137eafccb5896d5e55919f845

commit_message:
Stop allowing the deletion of an in-use flavor

Currently the API allows an operator to delete a flavor even when it
is in use by a load balancer. This patch corrects this by blocking
the deletion of a flavor that is currently in use by a load balancer.
It also correctly handles load balancers in the "DELETED"
provisioning_status.

Change-Id: Ie6d4f74e36c2fb7cee4e0ff1e198602c5d8394cc
Story: 2006782
Task: 37307

commit_message:
Remove fwaas_v1 extensions

There are still related extensions of fwaas_v1 in
neutron-fwaas, it is necessary to remove them because
the fwaas_v1 code has been removed in the Stein cycle[1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/616410/
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692068/
Change-Id: I26d23c74123302ef167bd621acdafd9e0e02c6a0
Closes-bug: #1850602

commit_message:
Start README.rst with a better title

Now that we are using gitea the contents of our README.rst are
more prominently displayed. Starting it with a "Team and repository
tags" title is a bit confusing. This change makes it start with the
name of the project instead.

While at it, also fix the intro and the CONTRIBUTING.rst mention,
for clarity.

Change-Id: Ibf4ae411d756744727a0aee24efdbdd561d0f522

subject: Do not get all resources if ID is passed
messages:
[{'account_id': 7249, 'date': '2019-11-06 09:39:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-11-11 15:08:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I've thought about this issue before and was tempted -- I'm just worried about the case where a user makes a uuid-named object. I've done this in testing before... Is it smart, and do we care? maybe not :D"}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-11-11 16:23:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Adam makes an interesting point. Maybe it should try a "get" on the uuid?
Also, we should include a release note with this.'}, {'account_id': 7249, 'date': '2019-11-12 11:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-11-13 19:06:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2019-11-14 02:30:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17130, 'date': '2019-11-14 03:01:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-11-19 17:46:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

This only addresses the "show" case -- which means that delete/update now technically follow a different code-path for lookups than a show.
That's a *little* concerning give that something could feasibly then cause a "show" to work fine, and a subsequent update/delete to fail or behave differently -- frustrating for a user, and not ideal.
I don't know exactly what case would cause that at the moment, but different code path == possible. I prefer to build things in a more guaranteed way, because otherwise what works today may not work tomorrow.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2019-11-19 18:35:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

OK, we can agree to have a followup theoretically at some point if someone has time eventually <_<'}]

commit_message:
Do not get all resources if ID is passed

Now function get_resource_id getting all resources even if exact
ID is passed.
And checking if ID is passed and call directly
to get exact resource. If direct call failed - try to get ID
as it was done before (important for case, when name is generated
in UUID format).

Change-Id: Ic66d5289afe1f8849e327f9347f9c3de8bb8b595
Story: 2006810
Task: 37365

commit_message:
Elasticsearch: Update base image

This updates the base image used for Elasticsearch version 7.1.0
to the open source base image instead of the base image with
the basic xpack licenses included

Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
Incorrect group name issue on non DPDK compute

This change is to fix the incorrect grouo name issue on non DPDK compute
node, currently pushes incorrect group 'hugetlbfs' to non DPDK node
instead of group 'qemu' when DPDK environment with 2 different roles
for compute nodes DPDK and non-DPDK.

Change-Id: I9462e0451b3be054568d951252fa7b1d3802c180
Closes-Bug: #1837034
(cherry picked from commit 76ee8f55fa845d74bda485cb85ac87a9059fc2a3)

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-11-19 14:38:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-11-19 14:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

Will switch to +2 pending the result of https://review.opendev.org/694949'}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-11-19 14:39:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

There are no jobs which test nova and devstack under python 2.7.  As long as that's the case, there is a hole in gate testing, and the default devstack installation could be broken again.  Indeed, there are no jobs running on this change which will verify that it is correct."}, {'account_id': 1, 'date': '2019-11-19 14:39:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-11-19 14:40:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694949/
is testing it via a depends on'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:08:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build SUCCESSFUL (check pipeline).

- pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered http://52.27.155.124/07/695007/3/check/pmem-tempest-plugin-filtered/2536d7c/ : SUCCESS in 28m 26s'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:24:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

We just had a long IRC conversation about this and the various alternatives.

The current state of things are that devstack's default is still py2, because some projects are still not ready for py3. The original deadline for changing that was January, but it has been on the books for a long time, and people are (rightly) concerned that it will get pushed again. Recently, the patch that this half-reverts was merged against nova, which makes it only installable in py3. That's a problem because (a) nova literally cannot be used in the default configuration of devstack and (b) any of those projects that are waiting for the py2 switchover are now already screwed because nova can't be installed.

One option is to fully revert the patch and go back to how things were until the switchover in January. That's not desirable because it would also revert a bunch of our own jobs that are now running in py3.

Another option is this patch, which reverts our minimum python version, but doesn't change anything else. The problem with this in isolation is that nova would be installed by default in devstack in py2 mode, but we don't have *any* testing of that anymore in our gate.

It seems that most people are in agreement with the following plan: We will do this half-revert, allowing nova to be installed in py2 mode where necessary. We will go ahead and merge the py3 devstack default switch now, which means nova will be gating on the default devstack configuration. Projects that are still not ready for py3 can force their jobs to py2 and install nova, but without any guarantees that recent changes haven't broken its use on py2. In January, when we would have thrown the master switch anyway, nova can un-revert the minimum python version part of the original change (i.e. this patch) to go back to py3-only.

My major concern was the difference between what we test and what the devstack default is. With this proposed plan, I'm happy so I'm +2ing this partial revert to unblock things and pave the way for the py3 devstack default to happen today."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:30:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:31:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:32:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I'm good with minimum installability support and keeping the fire lit under getting devstack to switch to py3 by default and force people to move. That's what I said in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694891/."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:52:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I'm good with minimum installability support and keeping the fire
 > lit under getting devstack to switch to py3 by default and force
 > people to move. That's what I said in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/694891/.

+1, i agree and what we discussed during py2 drop plan. if any cross dependency things break then force consumer to drop py2. with lot of cross dependencies via code or jobs installation it is hard to keep the smooth migration. I do not think keeping py2 job on nova is good idea. if non-py2 code is merged in nova then it is fine and consumer of nova to drop the py2 immeditaly."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:58:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Bug 1853166 has been opened to track this.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-11-19 16:34:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-39259 : FAILURE in 1h 54m 44s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-11-19 17:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/695007/3 : FAILURE in 2h 26m 04s'}]

commit_message:
(Temporarily) readd bare support for py27

Revert part of the changes from
Ie1a0cbd82a617dbcc15729647218ac3e9cd0e5a9

This way it is possible again for nova to be installed
using python 2, thus allowing other devstack-based
jobs to work until everything switches to python 3
according the plans.

While py2 support may break anytime, its days are limited anyway.

Change-Id: I99ff84e6c1c033c28d499b0b8ac17ac5b0565f61

commit_message:
Add report dialog to enable user feedback

This changes adds a dialog form to let user send feedback about anomalies
found in log files. The json POST is:

{
  "name": "mirror update failed",
  "project": "openstack/nova",
  "branch": "master",
  "job": "tox-py36",
  "logpath": "job-output.txt.gz",
  "uuid": "6daac7c3d930493ab94c3efd021c1dbb",
  "lines": [16, 20],
  "reporter": "irc-name"
}

Change-Id: I04bc2bad3f91f9c29ad33bb387b25e2764723543

Is there a better way to manage the vuejs dependency? Perhaps npm/yarn/etc is overkill for the moment, in which case would just simply vendoring in this dependency be a better option for now?'}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2018-07-12 09:08:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Is there a better way to manage the vuejs dependency? Perhaps
 > npm/yarn/etc is overkill for the moment, in which case would just
 > simply vendoring in this dependency be a better option for now?

I think it's fine to default to the public CDN. The option is just there for firewalled setup without CDN access.
The library is only 20k, so it shouldn't be too much to embed it in the response too. But then we loose browser caching..."}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2018-07-12 09:10:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7069, 'date': '2018-07-12 12:56:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2019-11-19 17:59:34.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

subject: Use current juju proxy config when running sync.
messages:
[{'account_id': 31282, 'date': '2019-11-13 22:41:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-11-13 22:42:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

subject: Corrected notifications for auditing.
messages:
[{'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-08-26 13:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-08-27 07:02:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-27 10:04:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-08-27 10:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)

Last time I put there oslo_messaging_notification and you texted me " the audit middleware docs state to use the [audit_middleware_notifications] section for this." So now I used audit_middleware_notifications and you are texting me "the audit middleware will default to using the oslo_messaging_notification configuration section" I am confused..'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-27 11:01:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > (1 comment)
 > 
 > Last time I put there oslo_messaging_notification and you texted me
 > " the audit middleware docs state to use the [audit_middleware_notifications]
 > section for this." So now I used audit_middleware_notifications and
 > you are texting me "the audit middleware will default to using the
 > oslo_messaging_notification configuration section" I am confused..

I did. I then did some more research and added the following comment:

"Actually I checked the code and it will default to using this section."

Sorry if it was not clear enough.

What I think would be useful is to make the existing notifications more configurable, as we recently did for keystone: https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/src/branch/master/ansible/roles/keystone/defaults/main.yml#L121.

Now you can just set keystone_default_notifications_topic_enabled to true. We could have something similar for these other services.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-08-27 12:34:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-08-27 12:49:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-08-28 14:00:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-08-28 15:45:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-08-29 11:51:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-29 12:06:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-09-03 09:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-09-24 09:24:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2019-09-26 08:52:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

As stated in the api-paste file comment, I'd prefer not need to maintain such files which often changes and will lead to a hard work of maintainability, we've had only keystone during v2 to v3 upgrade and had many issues with internal keystone changes

Consider my -1 not to code change that looks good to me but to the behavior, in any case I would not block this change if other cores think is fine to maintain such files.

As possible alternatives:

- Merge the user changes with the existing api-paste file in container
- Copy over the whole user defined api-paste config, same as we do with policies

Regards"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-09-26 09:00:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > As stated in the api-paste file comment, I'd prefer not need to
 > maintain such files which often changes and will lead to a hard
 > work of maintainability, we've had only keystone during v2 to v3
 > upgrade and had many issues with internal keystone changes
 > 
 > Consider my -1 not to code change that looks good to me but to the
 > behavior, in any case I would not block this change if other cores
 > think is fine to maintain such files.
 > 
 > As possible alternatives:
 > 
 > - Merge the user changes with the existing api-paste file in
 > container
 > - Copy over the whole user defined api-paste config, same as we do
 > with policies
 > 
 > Regards

+1 to Eduardo's comment. We don't want to maintain these paste files as they'll just go stale."}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-09-26 10:51:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-09-26 10:53:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

commit_message:
Corrected notifications for auditing.

Audit notifying for Cinder, Glance, Heat, Nova and Neutron API. Enabled
if enable_audit_middleware_notifications is set to "yes".
E.g. for rabbitmq

Change-Id: I51740d62db2c5346b25f4d6e8ccef71b77213566
Closes-Bug: #1837416

[{'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-11-13 07:26:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2019-11-13 07:42:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8367, 'date': '2019-11-13 08:05:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2019-11-13 08:15:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2019-11-13 08:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-11-13 09:50:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Tested rhel004 periodic with https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/23681/'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-11-13 10:30:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-11-13 10:33:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Thanks for that, I'll check what we need to change to get rid of /var/log/mariadb in a follow up review."}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2019-11-13 10:35:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Thanks for that, I'll check what we need to change to get rid of
 > /var/log/mariadb in a follow up review.

@dcibrain, and also need to check why only rhel8 got affected with this issue, centos is green without it."}, {'account_id': 16312, 'date': '2019-11-13 10:40:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-11-13 10:58:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-11-13 14:32:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2019-11-19 07:09:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-11-19 08:57:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Alex, Cédric,

We keep creating /var/log/mariadb on the host because the galera container created by pacemaker bind-mounts it [1].

IIRC The galera resource agent runs an initial database initialization without considering the configured log file, so until the resource agent is enhanced, we bind-mounted /var/log/mariadb/mariadb.log to not lose any log.

Ans that also explains why it worked in RHEL7, because docker creates the directory if it doesn't exist on the host, whereas podman doesn't.


[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/profile/pacemaker/database/mysql_bundle.pp#L362"}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-11-19 14:42:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

yes the point is it should be /var/log/container/mariadb and not /var/log/mariadb and puppet-tripleo should be updated. We shouldn't be creating any /var/log/<service> directories for things in containers"}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-11-19 16:52:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> yes the point is it should be /var/log/container/mariadb and not
 > /var/log/mariadb and puppet-tripleo should be updated. We shouldn't
 > be creating any /var/log/<service> directories for things in
 > containers

Sorry I was unclear, I agree we should migrate away from the old directories. I will revisit the situation with the dependency we have on upstream's resource-agent and see if we can tweak that bind-mount without updating the resource agent."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-11-19 17:36:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I guess i'm unsure where the resource agent runs, so if it's on the host I guess that makes sense. If it's in the container then the bind mount in puppet-tripleo can just be adjusted w/o a resource agent change"}]

commit_message:
Readd creation of /var/log/mariadb directory

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692850/ cleaned up the
legacy directories, but since then rhel8 jobs fails while
starting galera containers with error of missing
directory /var/log/mariadb, this patch adds it again.

Closes-Bug: #1851847
Change-Id: Iea081ecb3fc021fc796c93631ed6f663fd9580db

That's not true: the TC (gmann) send out tons of changes to properly switch the jobs to use python 3, during the weekend.

Agreed with mriedem. We don't have to support python2.7 any more which means we shouldn't. I don't want to hurt every other project though, so I'm happy to revert just the requirements.txt and (partially) setup.cfg changes temporarily and can help out on the DevStack front w.r.t. getting everything switched over to Python 3 by default."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-11-19 14:51:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Okay, let's kick the can :("}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-11-19 15:23:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

and we're back again. Think dansmith is commenting on [1] but to summarize, we're doing to merge [1], switch DevStack to use Python 3 by default [2], and then revert [1] at M2. This means anyone that needs some time to fix their jobs to work with Python 3 can set USE_PYTHON3=False and nova will still be installable.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695007
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649097"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-11-19 16:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

We went with https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695007/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-19 02:28:43.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Stop testing Python 2"

This reverts commit 14872caae1a51c7015dd7c509d0173df2e943ed4.

I totally get that you have to switch at some point and it will not be
pain free ... however ...

As of right now the patch to convert devstack to Python 3 by default
is still in WIP [1].  This means basically devstack is by default
broken by this (the setup.cfg change means that pip will bail when
installing with Python 2).

This flows on to other jobs; for example consumers of install-devstack
role [2] take defaults and are thus broken too.  I'm sure there will
be other examples.

I feel like we should make sure the devstack defaults are Python 3
first, give people a little time to deal with that, and then switch
this over.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649097/
[2] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/install-devstack

Change-Id: I816c2647c5bbdddfca2a623ee14e80793a23c045
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Stop testing Python 2"

This reverts commit 14872caae1a51c7015dd7c509d0173df2e943ed4.

I totally get that you have to switch at some point and it will not be
pain free ... however ...

As of right now the patch to convert devstack to Python 3 by default
is still in WIP [1].  This means basically devstack is by default
broken by this (the setup.cfg change means that pip will bail when
installing with Python 2).

This flows on to other jobs; for example consumers of install-devstack
role [2] take defaults and are thus broken too.  I'm sure there will
be other examples.

I feel like we should make sure the devstack defaults are Python 3
first, give people a little time to deal with that, and then switch
this over.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649097/
[2] https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/install-devstack

Change-Id: I816c2647c5bbdddfca2a623ee14e80793a23c045
